componenttextpreview: Yes. It's about 10% to total revenues. And our outlook commercial vehicle market this year is flat to down 1 point or 2, depending on market.
componenttext: Yes. It's about 10% to total revenues. And our outlook commercial vehicle market this year is flat to down 1 point or 2, depending on market.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And profitability would be roughly closer to the corporate average, or a little bit above?
componenttext: And profitability would be roughly closer to the corporate average, or a little bit above?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Profitability is in line with the corporate average.
componenttext: Yes. Profitability is in line with the corporate average.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, if you could just talk about sort of bids that are in process right now as we look at the potential for new business bookings in 2016 and how you think that may shape up. Is there a sort of increased activity, or is there a lit
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, if you could just talk about sort of bids that are in process right now as we look at the potential for new business bookings in 2016 and how you think that may shape up. Is there a sort of increased activity, or is there a little bit of leveling out?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the actual -- the pool of opportunities is actually higher. So the amount of activity that remains out there is actually higher than what it was in 2015, which is certainly a positive sign. So we would expect from a bookings standpoint to come in roug
componenttext: No, the actual -- the pool of opportunities is actually higher. So the amount of activity that remains out there is actually higher than what it was in 2015, which is certainly a positive sign. So we would expect from a bookings standpoint to come in roughly in line with what we booked in 2015 from a total new business bookings standpoint. The big opportunities tend to be around. As you can guess, active safety. We're seeing a big ramp-up in demand off of a small number, obviously, on vehicle electrification, including things like 48-volt, as well as a fair amount of activity on our traditional Powertrain products like GDi, Gas Direct Injection. So very good. Great deal of opportunity out there.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Johnson of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Johnson of Barclays.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I want to talk a bit about the Powertrain unit. A couple of questions. The organic growth of 4% in 4Q, was this expected? Was there commercial vehicle headwinds there? Secondly, what's the bridge to get to 8% growth in 2016? Does it have to do with t
componenttext: Yes. I want to talk a bit about the Powertrain unit. A couple of questions. The organic growth of 4% in 4Q, was this expected? Was there commercial vehicle headwinds there? Secondly, what's the bridge to get to 8% growth in 2016? Does it have to do with take rates? Does it have to do with program launches? And just thirdly, how are the dialogues vis-a-vis timing of customer programs going given where oil prices are and the sort of views about the cycle, which I know are more intense on Wall Street than perhaps in OEM headquarters.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we'll start with your last question first. We've seen no shifting in schedules from Powertrain, quite frankly, or any of our other businesses. We've seen absolutely none. With respect to the growth rate of the Powertrain business, in the fourth
componenttext: Yes. Well, we'll start with your last question first. We've seen no shifting in schedules from Powertrain, quite frankly, or any of our other businesses. We've seen absolutely none. With respect to the growth rate of the Powertrain business, in the fourth quarter and in the first quarter of this year, Powertrain segment growth will be a bit slower, primarily the result of a challenging comp in our aftermarket business. So if you remember, Brian, last year, we launched a major program with a U.S. independent aftermarket retailer that had very strong revenue. So that affects the year-over-year comp in the Powertrain segment. So that's one. Two, what you will see is consistent in reality with the balance of our businesses, based on the timing of the ramp-up of all these launches, growth is going to be stronger in the second half of the calendar year than it is in the first half of the calendar year, consistent with the margin explanation that Mark talked about. So we're still very optimistic about the Powertrain segment. The other thing to underscore though is we've talked about it in the past and I mentioned it again in my comments, we're starting to see more demand more of a ramp up in vehicle electrification, including things like 48-Volt. Those are very good for us. So 48-Volt  hybrid content is 4 to 5x the content that we have on a traditional car, full EV is 7x the content. 48-volt is an area that, quite frankly, a product that we'll be talking more with folks like yourselves about at our investor conference in April. But the great thing about it is it's 70% of the benefit at 30% of the cost for the OEs. So we think it's a great value proposition.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also on Powertrain, just to finish up, margins expanded in the quarter even though revenue ticked up on a headline basis, was down; on an adjusted basis was the slowest of your 3 segments. Is that because of the lack of launch activity? And I guess in
componenttext: And also on Powertrain, just to finish up, margins expanded in the quarter even though revenue ticked up on a headline basis, was down; on an adjusted basis was the slowest of your 3 segments. Is that because of the lack of launch activity? And I guess in general how should we be thinking about the keyless margin in that segment?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, launch activity was a little slower, but they're still relative to the other businesses. I think it's really the benefit of, as you recall, we've done a fair amount of footprint rotation in our Powertrain business and it's the benefit related to t
componenttext: I mean, launch activity was a little slower, but they're still relative to the other businesses. I think it's really the benefit of, as you recall, we've done a fair amount of footprint rotation in our Powertrain business and it's the benefit related to that footprint rotation.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one final strategic Powertrain question. Are you getting more software work around Powertrain just given sort of what went on with the major European manufacturer and their diesel issues centered around software? Is there any kind of desire
componenttext: Okay. And just one final strategic Powertrain question. Are you getting more software work around Powertrain just given sort of what went on with the major European manufacturer and their diesel issues centered around software? Is there any kind of desire of OEMs to have a second set of eyes on the software even if they could do it themselves internally?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's an interesting question. I don't think we've seen it as a result of that. However, as you know, there's more electrification. There's more software going into the Powertrain. So that is certainly an overall trend that we're seeing. I don't believe
componenttext: That's an interesting question. I don't think we've seen it as a result of that. However, as you know, there's more electrification. There's more software going into the Powertrain. So that is certainly an overall trend that we're seeing. I don't believe it's a result of the event that you're talking about.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Pat Archambault of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Pat Archambault of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Dave Tamberrino on for Pat. Our first question really relates to price downs. Just looking at the last 4 quarters, we've seen them accelerate from the 1.5% range to really exiting the year at 2%. One, what's driving that? And then secondl
componenttext: This is actually Dave Tamberrino on for Pat. Our first question really relates to price downs. Just looking at the last 4 quarters, we've seen them accelerate from the 1.5% range to really exiting the year at 2%. One, what's driving that? And then secondly, as we get a little bit longer here in the cycle, at least in North America, do you anticipate further pressure here?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question we get asked a lot. We've always said price downs will be in the range of 1.5% to 2%. Last year, I think we ended the year at 1.4%.  This year, we're at about 1.8%. The primary driver of that, quite frankly, is faster growth in
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question we get asked a lot. We've always said price downs will be in the range of 1.5% to 2%. Last year, I think we ended the year at 1.4%.  This year, we're at about 1.8%. The primary driver of that, quite frankly, is faster growth in the E&S business where price downs tend to be 2% to 3% versus our Powertrain business and EEA businesses that have lower price downs. With respect to added pricing pressure, our response is -- our customers always challenges for price downs. It goes down when times are good, it goes down when times aren't quite as good. So we would tell you, we haven't really noticed the environment changing.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then we're about 6 months removed now from the onset of the VW emission scandal. Just thinking about your business within Europe, have you seen any shift really in production or any of the take rates that are going on now within
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then we're about 6 months removed now from the onset of the VW emission scandal. Just thinking about your business within Europe, have you seen any shift really in production or any of the take rates that are going on now within the region?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Nothing out of the ordinary, no. Have not seen any change.
componenttext: No. Nothing out of the ordinary, no. Have not seen any change.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, in the U.S., looking at January numbers, at least for a couple of the OEMs, it looks like there were some excess inventory exiting January. We're really wondering if you've seen any changes in your OEM partners in terms of what prod
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, in the U.S., looking at January numbers, at least for a couple of the OEMs, it looks like there were some excess inventory exiting January. We're really wondering if you've seen any changes in your OEM partners in terms of what production schedules look like in the short term.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Listen, we've -- again, we understand the concern that people in the investment community have with respect to where we are in the cycle and what production schedules look like. We see none. We've seen absolutely no change in production schedules from
componenttext: No. Listen, we've -- again, we understand the concern that people in the investment community have with respect to where we are in the cycle and what production schedules look like. We see none. We've seen absolutely no change in production schedules from when we gave guidance originally a month ago  as well as what our outlook was in the fourth quarter of last year as it relates to 2016. So we've seen no change. I think if you go back and you track SAR in retail sales, January does tend to be a lower month relative to the other months in the year.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Brinkman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Brinkman of JPMorgan.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the 1Q margin guidance, 12.3% to 12.7%, can you quantify at all what the impact is in dollars or in margin from the China production inefficiencies, just to help us kind of better gauge the underlying rates? And then on the efficiencies, c
componenttext: Just looking at the 1Q margin guidance, 12.3% to 12.7%, can you quantify at all what the impact is in dollars or in margin from the China production inefficiencies, just to help us kind of better gauge the underlying rates? And then on the efficiencies, can you remind us of the cadence of them and whether you expect any sort of lingering impact as late as 2Q, for example.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, listen, the China piece in Q4 was roughly, call it, $20 million. $15 million to $20 million. Q1, we expect it to basically decline to roughly $5 million. So there'll be a lingering effect in Q1 and then it will fall in Q2. However, given launch activ
componenttext: Yes, listen, the China piece in Q4 was roughly, call it, $20 million. $15 million to $20 million. Q1, we expect it to basically decline to roughly $5 million. So there'll be a lingering effect in Q1 and then it will fall in Q2. However, given launch activity, there'll still be some of that incremental launch cost carry-on from Q4 into Q1, call it another, I don't know, $25 million roughly of launch costs in Q1 relative to a higher number, call it, roughly $60 million in Q4.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then just last question, it's a macro one. I see on Slide 20 that your industry assumption for China is plus 4% in 2016. That's reasonable, of course. I don't think anybody really knows, right? But I see that IHS is using pl
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then just last question, it's a macro one. I see on Slide 20 that your industry assumption for China is plus 4% in 2016. That's reasonable, of course. I don't think anybody really knows, right? But I see that IHS is using plus 6%. So I'm just curious about your decision to forecast less than them, whether that's due to something that you're seeing on the ground over there or is there a different view as to when the current strength in China pulls from -- does it pull from second half '16 instead of '17 after the incentives expire, as their forecast seems to imply? I just wanted to ask your thoughts on the margin since you have a bigger exposure and you've been there longer than most.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Listen, we -- I mean, the first thing, when you look at IHS, I think you need to make sure when we talk about market assumptions, we include commercial vehicle. So that does have an effect. And given the fact that we're flat to slightly down at comm
componenttext: Sure. Listen, we -- I mean, the first thing, when you look at IHS, I think you need to make sure when we talk about market assumptions, we include commercial vehicle. So that does have an effect. And given the fact that we're flat to slightly down at commercial vehicle versus past car growth, that will have some effect. I think in addition to that, there may be a little bit of conservatism built into our numbers. We still remain optimistic about the China market. Q4 growth was very strong, was, quite frankly, as we said before, a bit of a surprise. Our outlook for the balance of the year is solid growth. And if the market ends up being stronger, I think that is an upside to our overall outlook for the business.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Jonas, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Jonas, Morgan Stanley.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question. It's on the startup costs, and the question is kind of, is it unreasonable to assume, given the huge growth and very different technologies and sometimes untested technologies or let's say uncommercialized, let's say, in the E&S busines
componenttext: Just one question. It's on the startup costs, and the question is kind of, is it unreasonable to assume, given the huge growth and very different technologies and sometimes untested technologies or let's say uncommercialized, let's say, in the E&S business that you're going to see over the next couple of years, that some of the startup costs and launch costs, I should call them, are just regularly recurring for a while and can reasonably be assumed to weigh down on margins. And I asked that because I think everyone, at least on the sell side I've seen, has margins in E&S just going up inexorably each year. And I'm just wondering if there's like a scenario where the startup costs are -- we should have them running recurring, basically.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I...
componenttext: Yes. I...

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Or if not larger.
componenttext: Or if not larger.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, listen, relative to where we are today in the amount of launch activity at E&S, I'd say no. I think significant amount of launch activity, Adam, in Q4, Q1 and ramping down in Q2 at E&S. So I think you have some normalization. I think long-term ma
componenttext: Yes. No, listen, relative to where we are today in the amount of launch activity at E&S, I'd say no. I think significant amount of launch activity, Adam, in Q4, Q1 and ramping down in Q2 at E&S. So I think you have some normalization. I think long-term margins for E&S, from my perspective, remain in line with what our longer-term outlook was. And I think the question is -- the question I would ask myself is how aggressive in terms of investment in new technologies do we -- how aggressive do we want to be, how aggressive do we want to be in pursuit of those technologies, as well as that business. And I think that's something that we have the ability to calibrate on or off. And to the extent we decided to be more aggressive from an investment standpoint is something that makes sense financially and we're able to communicate to folks like yourself and you'd agree with the opportunity.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just ask a follow-up, please? We're seeing a lot nontraditional players getting involved in the software part of the car, whether it's safety or even on Powertrain. Now I couldn't help but notice that Chevy Volt just -- it seems like LG Corp. like b
componenttext: Can I just ask a follow-up, please? We're seeing a lot nontraditional players getting involved in the software part of the car, whether it's safety or even on Powertrain. Now I couldn't help but notice that Chevy Volt just -- it seems like LG Corp. like basically made 2/3 of the purchase building materials of that car. I'm sure you saw that, too. Is that factoring into your longer-term views of where the margins of, say, E&S or Powertrain could be? Is the pace of, let's say, nontraditional crowding progressing as you'd expect? Or is that something that -- is that a variable, a vector to think about?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, listen, it's something that we always think about. Today, it's not as a direct the competition in terms of space or places that we compete. So it hasn't have -- had an effect and it's something we watch closely. I mean, the Chevy Volt is a great
componenttext: Yes. No, listen, it's something that we always think about. Today, it's not as a direct the competition in terms of space or places that we compete. So it hasn't have -- had an effect and it's something we watch closely. I mean, the Chevy Volt is a great example. I mean, that's a car where we have close to $400 of content, so we have a pretty good position from a vehicle standpoint. But it's something we monitor very closely.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Spak of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Spak of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, I just wanted to follow-up on Adam's line of question a little bit. So obviously, there will always be launch costs. It sounds like they'll be a little bit lower. I guess so what I was wondering is how -- I mean, it seems like there's also going
componenttext: Actually, I just wanted to follow-up on Adam's line of question a little bit. So obviously, there will always be launch costs. It sounds like they'll be a little bit lower. I guess so what I was wondering is how -- I mean, it seems like there's also going to be a period of time where you take on this new business until it gets to a right normal run rate of profitability to ring out the most of the efficiencies you can. So as we get all these new business coming on, can you give some indication as to how long it takes to actually get to the proper run rate margin for the new business versus the core of the base business, if you will?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, 2 to 3 quarters. And I -- it depends what the product is, but 2 to 3 quarters, Joe. Not any longer than 3 quarters...
componenttext: Yes, no, 2 to 3 quarters. And I -- it depends what the product is, but 2 to 3 quarters, Joe. Not any longer than 3 quarters...

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then within E&S, sorry if I missed this, but is -- any breakdown between infotainment or active safety, or what really sort of drove that big backlog launch in the quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then within E&S, sorry if I missed this, but is -- any breakdown between infotainment or active safety, or what really sort of drove that big backlog launch in the quarter?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What drove the big -- it's really -- it's both. So active safety growth in the fourth quarter for Delphi was 66% for full year, we're well north of 50%. And we're launching infotainment programs where our growth in infotainment in 2016 is going to be roug
componenttext: What drove the big -- it's really -- it's both. So active safety growth in the fourth quarter for Delphi was 66% for full year, we're well north of 50%. And we're launching infotainment programs where our growth in infotainment in 2016 is going to be roughly 25%. So those are 2 very active product lines. And then the last is, again, I mentioned vehicle electrification. Our revenue growth in vehicle electrification product line is going to be well north of 50% in 2016. So those are all the big drivers of E&S.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. One more housekeeping. Maybe I'm wrong here, but I think you still didn't get the proceeds from the thermal China JV. Is that accurate? And when do you expect to get that?
componenttext: Okay. One more housekeeping. Maybe I'm wrong here, but I think you still didn't get the proceeds from the thermal China JV. Is that accurate? And when do you expect to get that?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'd expect second quarter of this year. But you're [indiscernible], we have not, but we expect to actually receive them in the second quarter.
componenttext: Yes, we'd expect second quarter of this year. But you're [indiscernible], we have not, but we expect to actually receive them in the second quarter.

componenttext: And that's roughly $200 million or so?

componenttext: $90 million, okay.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Leiker of Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Leiker of Baird.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe Vruwink for David. If I consider the quarterly cadence of what might be likely in China from a production standpoint, it would seem that growth rates probably decelerate as the year goes on and we might even hit a negative comp by Q4. I'm just
componenttext: This is Joe Vruwink for David. If I consider the quarterly cadence of what might be likely in China from a production standpoint, it would seem that growth rates probably decelerate as the year goes on and we might even hit a negative comp by Q4. I'm just wondering, does your guidance then imply that you're going to see net negative performance out of China maybe by Q4 in anticipation of meeting to make either headcount changes or line rate reductions for the production decline?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't -- I think if you look at it mathematically, it'd be much slower growth to a slight decline in Q4 as you look at the number. I don't think it'd be a significant headcount reduction if we had to do it, nor would it be costly. I mean, that's a
componenttext: Yes. I don't -- I think if you look at it mathematically, it'd be much slower growth to a slight decline in Q4 as you look at the number. I don't think it'd be a significant headcount reduction if we had to do it, nor would it be costly. I mean, that's a region where we can change our headcount very, very quickly.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the question is given what you saw in -- with the lay offs happening during summer, meeting to build staff back up Q3 and then incurring these costs Q4 and Q1. Is there any lessons learned where you might have -- you could've done something differ
componenttext: I guess the question is given what you saw in -- with the lay offs happening during summer, meeting to build staff back up Q3 and then incurring these costs Q4 and Q1. Is there any lessons learned where you might have -- you could've done something different, where as we get into of the back half and things might be softening or slowing, maybe the incrementals or the decremental's are better this time around.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, listen, I think once we normalize, I think the incrementals would be the same maybe a bit better. Listen, I would -- we obviously follow the markets very, very closely. The China market , the decline happened very rapidly. I think our view as a
componenttext: Yes. Well, listen, I think once we normalize, I think the incrementals would be the same maybe a bit better. Listen, I would -- we obviously follow the markets very, very closely. The China market , the decline happened very rapidly. I think our view as a management team here is we'd rather be in front of the cost reductions versus behind it. So I think it would be fair to ask a question, would you act as aggressively in hindsight without knowing that schedules are going to rebound as much as they had in the fourth quarter? Would you react as quickly and as aggressively? And I think we tell you we would, because we'd rather be in front of a slowdown versus behind it. And that's a part of the cultural DNA here. -- we have your. We talk a lot about growth. We talk a lot about opportunities from an innovation and technology standpoint. At the same time, over the last 2 years, we've closed close to 15 manufacturing facilities globally. So we're always focused on how do we manage the business, how do we increase the flexibility of the cost structure under the realization that we operate in a cyclical industry.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Lim of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Lim of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Several questions here. You added back more employees than you laid off in China, if I heard you correctly. Is that due to -- is that more due to surge production -- a surge in production? Or are you thinking that there's just maybe an incrementally a bet
componenttext: Several questions here. You added back more employees than you laid off in China, if I heard you correctly. Is that due to -- is that more due to surge production -- a surge in production? Or are you thinking that there's just maybe an incrementally a better outlook for you guys in 2016 in China than what you guided to?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It's what we needed to deal with the production, right? In reality here, not only was the a production ramp up significant, but it's revenue who is going to be less efficient and productive than a historical employee. Therefore, you need more.
componenttext: No. It's what we needed to deal with the production, right? In reality here, not only was the a production ramp up significant, but it's revenue who is going to be less efficient and productive than a historical employee. Therefore, you need more.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then on the restructuring side, I saw an uptick in Powertrain. Can you give us a little bit more color there? Was it more in Asia? Europe? And in theory, wouldn't that yield stronger margins in the coming quarters or the flow-through from the
componenttext: Got you. And then on the restructuring side, I saw an uptick in Powertrain. Can you give us a little bit more color there? Was it more in Asia? Europe? And in theory, wouldn't that yield stronger margins in the coming quarters or the flow-through from the restructuring activity?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, it would be primarily in Europe.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, it would be primarily in Europe.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And finally, and a little bit more of a housekeeping item. How should we think about operating income and revenue cadence from Q -- versus one half versus the second half?
componenttext: And finally, and a little bit more of a housekeeping item. How should we think about operating income and revenue cadence from Q -- versus one half versus the second half?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Well, revenue growth will be a couple points higher second half versus first half. And then margin expansion, with the exception of -- you'll see sequential increase in margin expansion with the exception of the third quarter, which as you know, David, with the shutdowns in Europe, the North America tends to be lowest-margin quarter.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you a little more detail on the content opportunity for you guys on the vehicle electrification. So you have been talking about really impressive numbers 4, 5x on the 48-volt and up to 7x on electrical vehicles. Can you maybe unpack a litt
componenttext: I wanted to ask you a little more detail on the content opportunity for you guys on the vehicle electrification. So you have been talking about really impressive numbers 4, 5x on the 48-volt and up to 7x on electrical vehicles. Can you maybe unpack a little bit what goes into these calculations? Is that pure electrical content increase, or does that net out also what you'd essentially lose in terms of Powertrain -- traditional Powertrain content? And does that assume any level of autonomous driving in there?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It doesn't assume anything on autonomous driving and it is a net number. So to the extent we're losing content on a fully electric vehicle, it doesn't include the content of an internal combustion engine. But it seems, like an Electrical Architecture, it'
componenttext: It doesn't assume anything on autonomous driving and it is a net number. So to the extent we're losing content on a fully electric vehicle, it doesn't include the content of an internal combustion engine. But it seems, like an Electrical Architecture, it's -- the wiring connectors associated with EVs or hybrids, at E&S, it's inverters, converters, hybrid control units. It's battery pack and controllers, not the battery. It's chargers. Powertrain is the supervisory controller. So it really affects each one of our segments.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So ultimately, in the fully electrified world, you would have massive segments in E&S and EEA, and then a shrunk --  much more than offsetting your shrunk segment in Powertrain?
componenttext: So ultimately, in the fully electrified world, you would have massive segments in E&S and EEA, and then a shrunk --  much more than offsetting your shrunk segment in Powertrain?

componenttext: Yes. I think that's depending on the size of the engine, if it's a hybrid. But I think in a simplistic and a basic way to look at it, you're absolutely right. Very good growth at E&S and EEA would potentially lower growth or a decline in Powertrain, roughly.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one question on China. So we've been seeing through this past year a bit of a mixed shift towards smaller engines, largely due to the tax gone on those engines, but also I think the gross coming from lower-tiered cities and maybe the lower
componenttext: Okay. And then one question on China. So we've been seeing through this past year a bit of a mixed shift towards smaller engines, largely due to the tax gone on those engines, but also I think the gross coming from lower-tiered cities and maybe the lower end of the market. Is that an opportunity for you? Because essentially, you can sort of like sell your GDis on these smaller engines, or is that a negative mixed implication because we're talking about customers that may be more price-sensitive or segments of the margin that are more price sensitive?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we would say this is an opportunity. At the end of the day, it's an opportunity. So first, to give you a perspective. 80% of our revenue in China is on platforms where the vehicles have a 1.6-liter engine or less. So just to put that in perspective, w
componenttext: No, we would say this is an opportunity. At the end of the day, it's an opportunity. So first, to give you a perspective. 80% of our revenue in China is on platforms where the vehicles have a 1.6-liter engine or less. So just to put that in perspective, with respect to the Powertrain technology needed to hit the CO2 targets in China, the OEs need things like GDi. Those are important aspects to have them hit their fuel economy standards. So they're areas of opportunity for us. They're definitely areas of opportunity.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Does your current share price impact your view of M&A? And by that I mean are you more inclined to take advantage of the market dislocation we're seeing? Or is M&A the more attractive alternative based on the visibility you have in your current pipeline? And are any deals maybe in advanced negotiations that might impact your share repurchase rate near term?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing to announce today. Listen, at the end of the day, we always try to be active and look what's out there from a technology and M&A opportunity. We have a pipeline of opportunities that we continue to evaluate, but we always look at M&A from a strate
componenttext: Nothing to announce today. Listen, at the end of the day, we always try to be active and look what's out there from a technology and M&A opportunity. We have a pipeline of opportunities that we continue to evaluate, but we always look at M&A from a strategic and financial return standpoint, and we look at it through the lens of where the current value of our stock is. And the reality is it does affect our view, right? It can't help but affect our view. But to the extent we could find a very compelling M&A transaction with really great synergies that we looked at, and relative to share repurchase, looked more attractive to driving long-term shareholder value, that's something that we would certainly do. To the extent there isn't something out there like that, we would certainly ramp up the pace of our share repurchase activity.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then just one extra question for me, please. Within your 2016 guidance, can you share any outlook you have for the light duty diesel mix? You mentioned there's really nothing out of the ordinary you're seeing. So maybe I should assume your outlook i
componenttext: Okay. Then just one extra question for me, please. Within your 2016 guidance, can you share any outlook you have for the light duty diesel mix? You mentioned there's really nothing out of the ordinary you're seeing. So maybe I should assume your outlook is similar to before. Maybe diesel trending a shade below production rate. And just curious to get your latest thoughts on CO2 standards, the role of diesel and if anything has changed in your mind over the medium to long term to hit fuel economy standards.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our view, light duty  diesel -- our view on light duty penetration rate hasn't changed and it's basically, there'll be some growth but albeit slow and penetration rates will actually decline in Western Europe. Having said that, based on our discus
componenttext: Yes. So our view, light duty  diesel -- our view on light duty penetration rate hasn't changed and it's basically, there'll be some growth but albeit slow and penetration rates will actually decline in Western Europe. Having said that, based on our discussions with all our OEs, all of them view diesel as absolutely critical to meeting the CO2 regulations that are out there. They have to have it. So it'll continue to be a Powertrain solution although it'll grow at a slower rate. I hope that answers your question. But no change in view. I mean, we had that view a year ago.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
