headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kayla, and I will be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Delphi Q1 2016, earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Elena Rosman, Delphi's
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Kayla, and I will be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Delphi Q1 2016, earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Elena Rosman, Delphi's Vice President of Investor Relations. Elena, you may begin your conference.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, Kayla. And thank you for joining Delphi's first quarter 2016 earnings conference call. To follow, along with today's presentation, our slides can be found at delphi.com under the investors section of the website. Consistent with p
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, Kayla. And thank you for joining Delphi's first quarter 2016 earnings conference call. To follow, along with today's presentation, our slides can be found at delphi.com under the investors section of the website. Consistent with prior calls, today's review of our actual and forecasted financials excludes restructuring and other special items, and will address the continuing operations of Delphi. The reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the back of the presentation and the press release.
Please see Slide 2 for a disclosure on forward-looking statements which do reflect Delphi's current view of the future financial performance which may be materially different from our actual performance.
Joining us today will be Kevin Clark, Delphi's President and CEO; and Joe Massaro, CFO and Senior Vice President. As seen on Slide 3, Kevin will provide an operations update as well as an overview of the quarter, and then Joe will cover the financial results and the 2016 outlook in more detail.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Kevin Clark.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Elena. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Excuse me. Before Joe gets to offers a result, let's provide some color of what was a great quarter for Delphi.So let's begin with the highlights on Slide 5. In summary, we had another
componenttext:
Thanks, Elena. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Excuse me. Before Joe gets to offers a result, let's provide some color of what was a great quarter for Delphi.
So let's begin with the highlights on Slide 5. In summary, we had another very solid quarter, meeting our commitments in delivering strong revenue and earnings growth. Adjusted revenue growth was 6%, driven by market share and content gains across the portfolio. Operating income increased to $509 million, margins expanded 20 basis points to 12.6%, and earnings per share increased 12% to $1.36. And lastly, we returned approximately $450 million of cash to shareholders.
We remain very confident in our 2016 guidance as originally communicated back in January. There is thing we see today that changes our view of the underlying macro environment, with something stronger than offsetting shortfalls elsewhere, I'll touch on the macros in greater detail on the next slide.
The ramp-up of new program launches will continue to drive accelerated revenue growth, and a strong focus on leveraging our robust business model will enable us to flex our cost structure to meet the challenges of virtually any environment.
In addition, we made a number of our recent investor update meeting in London. We unveiled a 40-vehicle solution, which improves engine performance while lowering CO2 emissions by more than 10%. I'll cover this in more detail later. We also announced the IRS Section 7874 issues behind us, and that we've prevailed in our appeal, concerning the phi should be treated as a U.K. tax entity under the U.S. tax code. And we announced a new $1.5 billion share repurchase program.  Coupled with the recent dividend increase, this underscores confidence in our medium and long-term outlook, which is driven by the safe, green and connected megatrends decorating new opportunities for Delphi, continued material manufacturing performance which is funding incremental growth investments and driving margin expansion which will translate into cash flow generation, providing additional levers to drive shareholder value.
During the quarter, we also acquired PureDepth, Inc, the leading provider of multilayer 3D display technology. Our collaboration with True Depth was on display on the consumer electronics show in a concept Mustang, which has driven significant customer interest.
Slide 6 is an update on our view of the macro environment, which as I just mentioned, continued to remain balanced relative the assumptions underlying our 2016 guidance. I'll hit a few of the highlights. Starting with positives on the left, regulatory trends and consumer demands continue to influence fuel economy, emissions and vehicle safety standards, driving content per vehicle growth. And we continue to expect steady growth in global vehicle production driven by continued growth in China, North America and Western Europe. 
Moving to the middle of the chart. Consistent with our initial planning assumptions, we expect commodities and pricing to remain relatively neutral for the balance of the year. While we're currently seeing a slightly stronger euro, this is being more than offset by the week in China is RMB, with China being meaningful part of our business. 
Moving to the challenges on the right, we've seen for the declines in vehicle production in both South America and Eastern Europe, and increased weakness in the global commercial vehicle market now expected to be down low single digits driven by double-digit declines in the North American off-highway market. 
Lastly, working closely with our suppliers and OEM customers to mitigate any near-term supply disruptions due to the recent earthquakes in Japan, which will affect the second quarter but will be made up during the balance of the year. Joe will provide more context on this a little bit later. Given the various puts and takes, our overall outlook remains in line with our prior guidance.
More on China on Slide 7. I just returned from the Beijing Auto Show where I met with several of our top customers. We heard a relatively consistent view with the China market both global and local OEMs remained very confident China will continue to drive increased global vehicle production, estimating 2016 growth in the 4% to 6% range, resulting from continued strong demand for SUVs and in crossovers. There's also increasing dialogue regarding new energy vehicles and electrification in this market, which given our product portfolio, provides further revenue opportunities. Delphi remains well-positioned in this market, and expect to grow 10 to 12 points above vehicle production in 2016, benefiting from market share gains and the trends towards higher content vehicle.
Growth in the China markets reflected in our new business bookings on Slide 8, which told approximately $7 billion during the first quarter. We had a number of important customer bookings as well as several conquest wins, including a major Electrical Architectural win with FCA on the RAM Truck in North America, Powertrain wins with [indiscernible] in China and Ford in North America, and the key entertainment wins with Volkswagen in North America as well as with SGM in China. 
The right side of the chart reflects the balanced geographic mix of our bookings which should will drive strong revenue growth over the next few years. The increased geographic and customer diversity ensures that we're not dependent on any one region, segment or customer for growth.
Now given our portfolio is safe, green and connected technology solutions, and our track record of false execution, we're increasingly becoming a strategic partner of choice for a number of our customers, which is reflected in our record bookings over the last few years.
Turning to Slide 9. These are just a few examples of launched programs driving revenue growth this past quarter. Our Electrical Architecture segment is benefiting from increased content on the BMW X5 some back onboard charger for plugin hybrid powertrains. Ultimate BMW, our Powertrain division launched several components on the new Active Tourer. And the Electronics and Safety division is launching multiple programs, including short range radar and the Kia Cadenza, and infotainment content on the Lincoln MKX, Buick Excelle and Dodge RAM Truck.
Moving to Slide 10. As we highlighted in our investor day and was reinforced in Beijing last week, customer interest in electrification is gaining momentum. Our customers increasingly see the need for electrification of the powertrain to close rgx gaps on CO2 emissions and fuel economy. and 48-Volt hybrids are the affordable, no compromise solution. An optimized Electrical Architecture system is necessary for the electrification of today's vehicles, which is the very foundation for our 48-Volt solution. Customer's response has been strong for [indiscernible] system solution which represents approximately 4x the content opportunity compared to a traditional internal combustion engine for Delphi.
Now in addition to the 2 global customer programs we've already been awarded, we've received a strong interest from several automakers to explore collaborating on this very interesting technology.
Turning to Slide 11. Delphi continues to be recognized for its technology leadership by both customers and industry experts. Delphi's proud to receive the first-ever General Motors Innovation Award for our V2X [ph] module, which will be introduced on the all-new Cadillac CT6. We are the first to the market with this breakthrough technology. We also won our 18th Automotive News PACE Awards, after once again, leading the industry with 3 nominations. The Dual Hub [ph] is a custom USB application that enables Apple CarPlay, allowing the radio and an iPhone to be recognized simultaneously as a host device. It's the only solution on the market with its versatile functionality. 
Leading in innovation is the foundation of our strategy for growth, and these industry awards are strong validation that we're solving our customer's most challenging problems with industry-leading technologies. 
Moving to Slide 12. Before I hand things over to Joe, I want to underscore commitment to driving consistent, sustainable and importantly, profitable growth. Since our IPO, we've completed several transactions that enhance our technology portfolio and better position us for the future. Our advanced technologies are aligned to the megatrends of safe, green and connected, positioning us for accelerated revenue growth.
Our lean cost structure and global footprint allows us to further leverage both our scale and regional capabilities to drive revenue growth and margin expansion. And lastly, we will continue to execute a very balanced and very disciplined capital allocation strategy to drive increased shareholder returns. Our track record conveys our execution capabilities, and we are very confident we will deliver continued outperformance for years to come.
I now want to turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. I'll start by covering our first quarter performance and then discuss our second quarter and full year 2016 guidance.Let's start with Slide 14, with a snapshot of our first quarter financial performance.
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. I'll start by covering our first quarter performance and then discuss our second quarter and full year 2016 guidance.
Let's start with Slide 14, with a snapshot of our first quarter financial performance. As Kevin mentioned, we were pleased with our results which reflected both strong revenue and earnings growth. Revenue was up 7% or 6% adjusted for currency, commodity, acquisitions and divestitures. Our operating margins expanded 20 basis points. Earnings per share grew 12%, largely the result of increased net income, and in the quarter, we purchased a 5.6 million shares totaling $370 million. The adjusted tax rate was 18% for the quarter.
Slide 15 provides greater detail of revenue for the quarter. Starting on the left, you can see we had strong sales growth, including the impact of M&A, primarily HellermannTyton, which had organic growth of 13% in the first quarter. 
Foreign exchange and commodities were slightly bigger headwind, primarily driven by dollar strengthening against the Chinese RMB and the price of copper. 
Moving to the right, North America, Europe and Asia saw strong growth in both -- on both the reported as well as on adjusted basis. And as you can see, the South American market remains very weak, and we are not planning on a near-term recovery.
Accordingly, we have taken significant steps in the past year to reduce our South American footprint and cost structure, including exiting our business in Argentina and reducing the number of Brazilian manufacturing facilities from 9 to 4. And while we remain able to serve our global customers in South America, we have significantly reduced the impact of the market downturn on Delphi.
Turning to operating income. Slide 16 walks the year-over-year change for the first quarter. Our operating results are consistent with our expectations. Strong flow-through from a volume growth contributed to the margin expansion in the quarter, helping to offset the impact of launching growth related activities in our net performance. The impact of the China volume ramp and the added cost to support new program launches in E&S and EEA totaled approximately $35 million in the quarter. The China inefficiencies discussed previously represented approximately $5 million in Q1 and will not have an impact going forward.  The remaining launch costs will further moderate over the course of the year, and continued to be factored into our full year 2016 guidance.
Slide 17 takes us to the performance by segment. Electrical Architecture had adjusted growth of 5%, and HellermannTyton contributed approximately $200 million of revenue in the quarter. EEA margins expanded 70 basis points year-over-year. 
Powertrain also delivered 5% organic growth driven by gas systems, partially offset by lower commercial vehicle volumes. And Powertrain continues to deliver strong margins despite nearly 40 basis points of FX headwinds, primarily driven by the Chinese RMB. Electronics and Safety organic growth accelerated to 13% on new program launches, particularly in active safety and infotainment programs in Europe and China, partially offset by lower mechatronic sales, which represented a 3% negative impact on E&S growth in the quarter.
Active safety and infotainment continued to see strong growth of approximately 70% and 10%, respectively. Our E&S margins of 10.3% were as expected and reflect the launch related activities I just discussed.
As it relates to the remainder of 2016, we expect continued strong growth from new launches and from margins to expand over the course of the year as we ramp production volumes and improve performance.
Turning now to Slide 18. We saw total EPS growth of $0.15 or 12% for the quarter, including $0.11 from increased earnings. Share repurchases contributed $0.07, more than offsetting the impact of a higher tax rate. As you know, the tax rate can vary very from quarter-to-quarter, however, there's no change to our 17% full-year estimate. 
Now turning to the outlook on Page 19. As Kevin mentioned, given the puts and takes, there are no changes to the 2016 guidance. Revenue is driven by accelerating organic growth throughout the year and the full year effect of the HellermannTyton acquisition. We expect to expand margins by roughly 50 basis points, and 2016 EPS is expected to be in the range of $5.80 to $6.10, reflecting year-over-year growth of 14%. 
Second quarter revenue was forecast in the range of our $4.125 billion to $4.225 billion. This includes the impact of the supply disruptions from the Japanese earthquake, estimated to be $75 million of revenue and $20 million of operating income at the midpoint of our guidance. While we continue to monitor and assess the potential impacts, conversations with our customers indicate that any near-term production disruptions will be made up over the balance of the year.
We expect second quarter EPS in the range of $1.50 to $1.60, up 16% at the midpoint, which includes the impact from the earthquake supply disruptions. Our strong balance sheet and capital allocation strategy outlined on Slide 20 remains an important leverage to enhance shareholder value. 
On the left, we expect cash flow from operations to grow approximately $2 billion, up almost 20% in 2015. And the deployment priorities on the right are consistent with our strategy, maintaining a strong balance sheet and investment-grade rating.
We are investing in our business to increased capital expenditures, supporting new program launches, information systems that increase efficiency and productivity and ongoing footprint rotation to best cost centers. We are committed to paying a competitive dividend, and to the extent we have excess cash, we have a track record of returning it to shareholders via share repurchases, as evidenced by the $370 million of repurchases we did in the first quarter.
As we state here today, we do not expect repurchases to continue with the first fourth quarter pace. However, would tend to be opportunistic while remaining committed to executing a balanced and disciplined capital allocation framework.
Now before I hand things back to Kevin, and turning to Slide 21, we are focused on executing value enhancing portfolio modifications. As such in the quarter, we completed the final step in the divestiture of the thermal business of the sale of our stake in the Chinese joint ventures.  And we have acquired PureDepth, a leading provider of [indiscernible] 3D multilayer. You can expect us to continue to pursue investments that enhance our existing technology portfolio, [indiscernible] competitive position and drive increased value for our shareholders.
I'll now turn it over to Kevin for some closing remarks before we open up the call for questions.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Now summarizing on Slide 21. We delivered another strong quarter, executing on the relevant advanced technologies that enable us to outgrow the markets we serve.We believe we're well positioned to deliver on our commitments in 2016, high si
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Now summarizing on Slide 21. We delivered another strong quarter, executing on the relevant advanced technologies that enable us to outgrow the markets we serve.
We believe we're well positioned to deliver on our commitments in 2016, high single-digit organic growth, roughly 50 basis points of margin expansion, solid mid-teens EPS growth and $1.2 billion of free cash flow. 
We continue to optimize our cost structure, increase the flexibility of our workforce and execute flawlessly. We're investing and profitable growth where we see opportunities. We remain disciplined in our allocation of capital, investing in both organic and inorganic growth, and returning excess cash to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.
Through all of this, we continue to demonstrate our ability to deliver on our commitments even against the backdrop of a dynamic environment.
So with that, we'll now open up the line for questions.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Rod Lache from Deutsche Bank.

componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions. One is on the pricing, it looks like it came in at 2.1% this quarter.  I Know you've consistently guided to 2%, but it's been running lower up until recently. And I was wondering if this is just growing -- Electronics and Soft
componenttext: I had a couple of questions. One is on the pricing, it looks like it came in at 2.1% this quarter.  I Know you've consistently guided to 2%, but it's been running lower up until recently. And I was wondering if this is just growing -- Electronics and Software and how you are looking at offsetting that? And then also, notice that the FX /commodity impact on the EBIT bridge, was positive -- it looked like is was negative on the top line. Is that somehow related to transactional effects with the euro appreciating versus the EE currencies, or is that something else?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So why don't I start on the pricing and then you can add, Joe, and then talk about FX and commodities. So Rod, with respect to guidance on pricing, we remain -- our guidance in the range of 1.5% to 2% pricing. I think this quarter was slightly higher than
componenttext: So why don't I start on the pricing and then you can add, Joe, and then talk about FX and commodities. So Rod, with respect to guidance on pricing, we remain -- our guidance in the range of 1.5% to 2% pricing. I think this quarter was slightly higher than that. Given our much faster growth in E&S over the next 12 months, growth is roughly double our overall corporate growth, and as we've talked about in the past, E&S tends to have price downs of 2% to 3% versus the balance of our portfolio that is less than 2% and the rapid growth in that segment is what's driving the overall increase in price downs on a year-over-year basis. Other than that, nothing has changed from a business model standpoint. Joe, do you want to?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Rod, on the FX commodities, we did -- as we mentioned a couple of times during the prepared remarks, the RMB did impact as negatively during the quarter, from both the revenue and NOI perspective. Apart from that, everything else was fairly balanced
componenttext: Sure. Rod, on the FX commodities, we did -- as we mentioned a couple of times during the prepared remarks, the RMB did impact as negatively during the quarter, from both the revenue and NOI perspective. Apart from that, everything else was fairly balanced out. We also did see about a $40 million headwind from copper, a decreased copper pricing in the quarter. But we've talked about before, that has a very low ROI flow-through given the fact that we mostly have passthroughs to customers and have the rest hedged out. So revenue, slightly bigger impact, OI with the exception of the CNY, everything else sort of balances out.

componenttext: Yes. No, I mentioned we're about $30 million in launch costs across the E&S and EEA in Q1, another $5 million for China. But $5 million does go way. componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Then just a second question, I mean, there was relative strength in Europe, up 9%. I'm just curious if you're seeing anything going on there with mix or take rates on some of your product? And also, in conjunction with that, you've kind of hi
componenttext: Okay, great. Then just a second question, I mean, there was relative strength in Europe, up 9%. I'm just curious if you're seeing anything going on there with mix or take rates on some of your product? And also, in conjunction with that, you've kind of highlighted the idea that you had further costs, rotational low cost sourcing. I'm just curious what's going on on the revenue line or in the mix, and then also on the cost side and the potential going forward?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And so I'll start. Listen, in Western Europe, we're seeing the benefits of a stronger market. I would say that's partially offset by weakening in Russia. With respect to the strong growth, I'd really tie it to market improvement as well as just timin
componenttext: Yes. And so I'll start. Listen, in Western Europe, we're seeing the benefits of a stronger market. I would say that's partially offset by weakening in Russia. With respect to the strong growth, I'd really tie it to market improvement as well as just timing of launch of new programs, John. I don't think it's anything particular to what -- where you need to content gains or anything like that. With respect to footprint, Joe should comment on this, we continue to aggressively attack our cost structure, a big piece of the restructuring that we've been doing over the last few years, we will continue to do, just focused on rotating footprint out of Western Europe into Eastern Europe.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think, John, as we've been able to do over the years, you've seen us, maybe initially move the EEA or some of the E&S plants to Eastern Europe. We're now at a point where we can move some of the powertrain facilities which are much more complic
componenttext: Yes. No, I think, John, as we've been able to do over the years, you've seen us, maybe initially move the EEA or some of the E&S plants to Eastern Europe. We're now at a point where we can move some of the powertrain facilities which are much more complicated manufacturing processes but we've now built a base of powertrain capabilities in Eastern Europe, and we're starting to move those production activities east as well. So that's a continued process, and I think getting in line with our overall best cost country rotation plan as well as our margin outlook for the coming years.

componenttext: So as we think about that, I mean what's the opportunity, because I mean you seem like a lot of that had been executed already, but this time, it's like a good piece in -- I mean are you halfway done, or 3 quarters away done? componenttext: I think it will certainly help us maintain our current labor dollars. As you think about just globally, there's obviously up and downs in labor economics, and part we're doing this to sort of maintain our position. I would say as you think about powertrain, they're really in the first 1/3 of its rotation, is the way I would think about it.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean John, if I can -- so listen, everything we do have -- just have a very positive returns. So it's 2 things: It's one, to Joe's point, about strategically repositioning our footprint over the long term, so that we maintain the industry's most competi
componenttext: I mean John, if I can -- so listen, everything we do have -- just have a very positive returns. So it's 2 things: It's one, to Joe's point, about strategically repositioning our footprint over the long term, so that we maintain the industry's most competitive cost structure. And it's all about driving increased returns. So net-net, yes, there's an incremental profit improvement impact that will flow-through our numbers in the out years. So there's certainly is a benefit on top of maintaining our current cost structure and actually improving it.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay that's helpful. And then lastly, there's some incremental wins going on here on infotainment. I'm just curious, are you gaining market share there? And curious, if you are, is that just purely because of content or is that also your ability to backwa
componenttext: Okay that's helpful. And then lastly, there's some incremental wins going on here on infotainment. I'm just curious, are you gaining market share there? And curious, if you are, is that just purely because of content or is that also your ability to backward or to integrate -- not backward, but integrate into the Electrical Architecture of the vehicle?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I -- we don't really sell that as a package. I think underpinning everything we do from an vehicle electrification, system integration standpoint, I think we would tell you we are at a competitive advantage given our Electrical Architecture c
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I -- we don't really sell that as a package. I think underpinning everything we do from an vehicle electrification, system integration standpoint, I think we would tell you we are at a competitive advantage given our Electrical Architecture capabilities, because for all the ebb and flows of Electrical Architecture's important component on there. So internally, we certainly partnering and work together. But in terms of how we go to the customer, customers tend to buy specific products. Our bookings in E&S has been close to $2 billion per year -- each year over the last 4 years, we'd expect to -- actually over $2 billion. We'd expect the book roughly $2 billion again this year which is roughly 2x our current run rate from a revenue standpoint. Infotainment is going to be our fastest-growing, our -- one of our fastest-growing segments, growing roughly 20% over the next few years. That's faster than the overall market. I think we're benefiting from where we sit in medium and high end systems where you see content growth. And then we're probably also gaining some share in certain markets.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Brian Johnson from Barclays.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to talk a little bit of PureDepth, especially in the context of cockpit electronics and infotainment. Maybe, a couple of things. Where are you right now in terms of cockpit electronics or what we would call dashboards? Second, how do you see that p
componenttext: I want to talk a little bit of PureDepth, especially in the context of cockpit electronics and infotainment. Maybe, a couple of things. Where are you right now in terms of cockpit electronics or what we would call dashboards? Second, how do you see that playing out in the next 3 to 5 years long, a couple of dimensions, first, the transition from gauges and dials to flat screens, or guess for you, 3D flat screens? And then kind of when do you expect that inflection? And second, to what extent will this be purchased by OEMs as a module, along with the center stack infotainment, or still as separate purchase? And then finally, any details on PureDepth in terms of transaction amounts, if you could disclose it?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Joe can talk about the transaction amount. Why don't I start with where we are. Clearly -- I think Brian, as you know, the cockpit is moving to digital and what PureDepth gives us is effectively enhanced graphics and 3D capabilities. I can tell you t
componenttext: Yes. Joe can talk about the transaction amount. Why don't I start with where we are. Clearly -- I think Brian, as you know, the cockpit is moving to digital and what PureDepth gives us is effectively enhanced graphics and 3D capabilities. I can tell you the Consumer Electronic Show, and I know you visited our booth, the 3D graphics on the cluster we had got more attention from our customers than any other technology that we showed at the CES including our automated driving capabilities. So it is a very interesting technology that we're integrating into our cluster business. Where we sit today? We saw clusters, we saw center stacks. With infotainment systems, you're going to see more display, you're going to see more glass in cars, or convince them that, that you're going to see that happen over the next 2, 3, 4, 5 years. And from our perspective, it's important that we're well situated, and we believe we are, and we can reflected in our strong infotainment wins. The cluster business is a business that is for us, not real large today but is growing rapidly. And we think PureDepth's technology is something that will help us advance our growth. Joe, do you want to...

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. From a transaction perspective, just a couple of things, relatively small from a valley perspective, about $50 million we paid for the acquisition of PureDepth. We've worked closely with PureDepth as CES showed over the last couple of years s
componenttext: Sure, Brian. From a transaction perspective, just a couple of things, relatively small from a valley perspective, about $50 million we paid for the acquisition of PureDepth. We've worked closely with PureDepth as CES showed over the last couple of years so we know them well. Integration was fairly easy. We've basically completed it, and this is in the deal that will have a long run of integration. So it's now tucked in the development efforts -- are underway, as they are now fully owned company versus just development partners. So it's -- they were pretty much taking cared of in the quarter.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you're -- today, it varies a bit by customer. Some customers, there are separate buying groups and engineering groups. But they are increasingly becoming more integrated with the infotainment function. And that is a trend and it will continue.
componenttext: No, I think you're -- today, it varies a bit by customer. Some customers, there are separate buying groups and engineering groups. But they are increasingly becoming more integrated with the infotainment function. And that is a trend and it will continue.

componenttext: Maybe just a question on the organic growth in the second half of the year given some of the moving parts around Japan and the backlog. Can you maybe help us think about Q3 and Q4, and also maybe what your rough backlog split is between the first half and second half this year?

componenttext: Sure, Itay. It's Joe. Obviously, first quarter we saw a 6% organic growth. Second quarter, we're right around 8%, just a little under 8%. Japan is worth about 2 points of that. But right now, we're looking to 12% growth and 10% growth, Q3, Q4.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would -- certainly not the Q3 activity -- I'm sorry, the Q1 activity. We're obviously, fairly aggressive in Q1, saw the dislocation in the marketplace. And as we said, we will be opportunistic as those things happen. I think for a modeling perspect
componenttext: Yes, I would -- certainly not the Q3 activity -- I'm sorry, the Q1 activity. We're obviously, fairly aggressive in Q1, saw the dislocation in the marketplace. And as we said, we will be opportunistic as those things happen. I think for a modeling perspective, Itay, as we said, be around $50 million to $75 million per quarter. I think we're going to -- we've got to -- we're going to be obviously continuing down the path of our capital allocation strategy but we'll be mindful of M&A opportunities -- and the stocks obviously come up of the lows that we saw in the February time frame. So we'd be thinking $50 million to $75 million is probably the right modeling perspective, realizing we will obviously reserve the right to be opportunistic as well going forward.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Great. Just lastly, quickly -- I mean for Kevin. Just with the conquest wins you've been able to have and $7 billion of Q1 bookings, any -- I know it's early in the year, but any initial thoughts of where maybe bookings can track this year relative to prior years?

componenttextpreview: Yes. I would -- Itay, I would expect bookings to be roughly at the levels that we did last year, $26 billion or a bit more. That can be affected by timing of awards. So I'll warn you on that. But given our current line of sight and given the number of opp
componenttext: Yes. I would -- Itay, I would expect bookings to be roughly at the levels that we did last year, $26 billion or a bit more. That can be affected by timing of awards. So I'll warn you on that. But given our current line of sight and given the number of opportunities and the estimated timing of those opportunities, we should be at roughly $26 billion [indiscernible]

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Patrick Archambault from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Patrick Archambault from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just 1 quick follow-up on the Japan issue. I mean, can you just mentioned that a little bit for us -- I know there was another company also in infotainment that had an impact as well. And what's the visibility? I mean, how broad based has this impact
componenttext: Yes. Just 1 quick follow-up on the Japan issue. I mean, can you just mentioned that a little bit for us -- I know there was another company also in infotainment that had an impact as well. And what's the visibility? I mean, how broad based has this impact been on your supply chain? Are some of these facilities now beginning to kind of turnaround and start produce, like is there indivisibility what come back online? What's your confidence on when that comes back?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I think there's a reasonable amount of visibility, but I would say, the situation is evolving, Patrick. I think as an industry from a supply chain standpoint, we do a very good job of -- and this is across the board -- This is supply base as
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I think there's a reasonable amount of visibility, but I would say, the situation is evolving, Patrick. I think as an industry from a supply chain standpoint, we do a very good job of -- and this is across the board -- This is supply base as well as the OEs -- working together to identify where issues are, and identifying either alternative sources to manufacturer or substitute products that OEs approve, to mitigate the overall impact of these types of situations. So we all have a vested interest in much visibility as possible, and that we're working together to resolve the problem to ensure that ROEs have the product to build the car. Joe, maybe you could comment more on the numbers.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I think, from a -- again, as we look at the numbers, obviously, a lot of dialogue with the suppliers -- we have 2 suppliers, 1 a little bit more significant than the other that's impacted here. Obviously, talked to the customers as well. I wou
componenttext: Sure. Well, I think, from a -- again, as we look at the numbers, obviously, a lot of dialogue with the suppliers -- we have 2 suppliers, 1 a little bit more significant than the other that's impacted here. Obviously, talked to the customers as well. I would say the -- to put it in perspective, if you could take back to the tsunami, there you had physical damage to manufacturer facilities, and that tended to be over a longer period of time. What we've been told so far and what we're seeing, this is more a case of damage to in-process inventory than the facilities themselves. So that gives us some confidence that the delays will be both short-term in nature and recovery should be quicker. At the midpoint, we've estimated $75 million of revenue. That includes both direct. That's about 50-50 both direct impact as well as indirect. So direct would be where we don't have supply and can't ship to a customer. Indirect, and GM is a good example of that, would be a case where customer has told us they're impacted by another supplier. It won't be producing, so they're probably not going to ship to them either. At the high end, it could be $100 million of revenue and close to $30 million of OI. That's reflected in the low end of our guidance. So high end of Japanese risk, low end of our guidance. At the high-end of our guidance range, it's about $50 million of revenue and $10 million of OI.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Patrick, we have a team of supply chain and manufacturing people who are -- who have been in Japan now for weeks, working with the supply base there as well as with our customers trying to develop and then ultimately, implement solutions to any of these p
componenttext: Patrick, we have a team of supply chain and manufacturing people who are -- who have been in Japan now for weeks, working with the supply base there as well as with our customers trying to develop and then ultimately, implement solutions to any of these problems. So it's very proactive.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. No, I appreciate of the details on that -- very helpful. Just 1 second question. I mean, we've touched on at the little bit in this call so far, but can you just remind us -- I mean, obviously, the CAGR that you've outlined in the infotainment bus
componenttext: Got it. No, I appreciate of the details on that -- very helpful. Just 1 second question. I mean, we've touched on at the little bit in this call so far, but can you just remind us -- I mean, obviously, the CAGR that you've outlined in the infotainment business back to the Analyst Day of 20%, it's double your industry forecast of TAN -- double or pretty close to double ours as well. So can you just remind me -- clearly, there's been a lot of concept opportunity there and some share gains but specifically, where are you winning business from others, that's allowing you to see so much relative growth, if you well?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at growth in infotainment, it really -- for us, it's across the board by region, it's probably, fastest growing as you can imagine in China, off of a lower [ph] number when you think about the China market. For us, that's -- for players like
componenttext: When you look at growth in infotainment, it really -- for us, it's across the board by region, it's probably, fastest growing as you can imagine in China, off of a lower [ph] number when you think about the China market. For us, that's -- for players like ourselves, I characterize it as perfect opportunity, as solid vehicle production growth, as well as when you look at mix the vehicles, they tend to be higher end -- SUVs, crossovers or sedans with a significant content. And given the fact that there's significant content and we're winning business in regions, in the areas like that, we're benefiting from that stronger, much stronger mix. But we're also -- we've won and we're launching big wins with some of the European OEs, both what I call, the mass market, as well as the luxury as well as here in the U.S.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Ryan Brinkman from JPMorgan.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: May be one more on PureDepth. Just for my quick googling here this morning, it seems like there was a strong non-autos market focus prior to the acquisition, primarily in the sort of gaming and mobile industry. So I'm sure the motivation obviously is enhance your technology capabilities and drive Infosystems. But like what HellermannTyton, are you happy to continue with the nonautomotive business as well and then what's your general philosophy toward non-auto businesses and that may sort of peripherally come along as you make, I guess, increasingly technology-type acquisitions?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. And listen, it's a great question. The original technology started in the gaming industry. And in fact, we're not here to announce we're heading into gaming. The reality is if that has been a technology that they defocused in, it's running off, and th
componenttext: No. And listen, it's a great question. The original technology started in the gaming industry. And in fact, we're not here to announce we're heading into gaming. The reality is if that has been a technology that they defocused in, it's running off, and the sole focus is and on the automotive space. But that is where their roots actually began, Ryan. So it's a very good question.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just last 1, I thought to check in with another quarter past that Volkswagen emissions issue, have you seen any sort of corollary uptick in interest inm 48-Volt products, because there are some articles recently discussing how where as Europe was
componenttext: And then just last 1, I thought to check in with another quarter past that Volkswagen emissions issue, have you seen any sort of corollary uptick in interest inm 48-Volt products, because there are some articles recently discussing how where as Europe was maybe behind Japan in the U.S. in terms of electrification that -- maybe now, there's going to be a big infection. So perhaps, remind what is embedded in the long-term guidance from the Analyst Day relative to electrification in Europe. And I'm curious if it already incorporates a big increase, or whether there might be a more upside based upon your latest conversations?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, listen, I mean our outlook for electrification is this -- is kind of high -- it's -- what is it, roughly 25% or 20%, 25%, a couple of points of EV -- or sorry, 20%, 25%, about 2 points of that mix is pure EVs. The balance is hybrid and 48-Volt and o
componenttext: Well, listen, I mean our outlook for electrification is this -- is kind of high -- it's -- what is it, roughly 25% or 20%, 25%, a couple of points of EV -- or sorry, 20%, 25%, about 2 points of that mix is pure EVs. The balance is hybrid and 48-Volt and our estimate is -- 48-Volt is roughly half, so call it 9 or 10 points. I think that reflects fairly rapid growth on the hybrid and 48-Volt side. If you look at IHS and based on conversations with the customers, that mix of EV and hybrids out in 2025 is actually increased over the last 6 months. And listen, I say their members may be an opportunity that accelerates further. Clearly, there's more dialogue and more interest from our customers as they focus on solutions to reducing CO2 emissions and increasing fuel economy, and things like 48-volt where you can get a significant benefit at a fraction of the cost, it's a great value proposition. It's a terrific value proposition. So we're having increasing dialogue, and it's really across the globe. It's not just in Europe and in North America, there's actually a couple of customers in China that we're working with now on 48-Volt systems solutions. And what positions us really, really well as you think about being in the Powertrain business and the electronic and safety and then importantly, in that Electrical Architecture business, we actually have solutions to every single aspect you need to provide us a complete system solution to the OE.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Leiker from Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Leiker from Baird.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up a little bit on the discussion that Ryan was just going through -- India and China, around the auto show, and you walked the floor there. It seems like much more interest in electrification than here in the U.S. And I was just wondering if you
componenttext: A follow-up a little bit on the discussion that Ryan was just going through -- India and China, around the auto show, and you walked the floor there. It seems like much more interest in electrification than here in the U.S. And I was just wondering if you could talk about these new energy vehicles, as they're calling them, and bringing them to market? And maybe you answered part of this, but a little bit more focused specifically terms of the opportunity in China, where Delphi's positioned relative to competition there in the products and technologies capabilities that you have that you can bring to market there?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So when you think about it, let me start with, as you know, you were just there. We've been in the China market for close to 25 years serving the China market and when you look at our capabilities everywhere from engineering, design, development, to
componenttext: Sure. So when you think about it, let me start with, as you know, you were just there. We've been in the China market for close to 25 years serving the China market and when you look at our capabilities everywhere from engineering, design, development, to manufacturing, I would say there isn't a supplier author that has the same capabilities. And we're localized in virtually, all of our product lines. I think of our 3D [indiscernible] 30 or 31 are localized. So we have the full portfolio that we can provide to our customer base in region. And we can meet their needs from a design standpoint as well as the costs standpoint. And I think that starts with Electrical Architecture. I think it's augmented with inverse and converters, battery packs, things like that, that we can bring to bear. And those products that we don't manufacturer today like electric motors, there are partners that we're using strategically to sell the whole system solution. When you look at the market, if there's a market that is right for electrification, where it should be easier to implement, it's the China market. Based on discussions with both the globals as well as the local EEs, everyone is convinced that the government is focused on enforcing regulations and reducing CO2 emissions and addressing the pollution problem. So enforcement this there. The infrastructure investment is easy to make. And from a growth standpoint, it's probably -- it probably is one of the biggest opportunities. We'll see how quickly it comes to fruition though at this point in time.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just another item here on the ADAS cars autonomous vehicles. I just want to get a perspective of where you stand today on your capabilities to essentially, provide a turnkey solution to an automaker who might be found lacking a bit in the investm
componenttext: And then just another item here on the ADAS cars autonomous vehicles. I just want to get a perspective of where you stand today on your capabilities to essentially, provide a turnkey solution to an automaker who might be found lacking a bit in the investment, or behind the pack of some of the leaders in this space? You get the point that you can offer a turnkey solution to an automaker who must to play catch-up?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We can certainly offer a turnkey solution from a technology standpoint, and we are having dialogues with the various parties with respect to that. I think that challenge for both customers as well as folks like ourselves are twofold: Near term, it's
componenttext: Yes. We can certainly offer a turnkey solution from a technology standpoint, and we are having dialogues with the various parties with respect to that. I think that challenge for both customers as well as folks like ourselves are twofold: Near term, it's cost and how do we sell commercially effective solutions. And then second is the regulatory/legal environment, and how you cross those bridges. I mean, as we said in the past, the biggest challenge is fully automated is not going to be the technology or the cost, it's really going to be regulation and legal liability. I think the important thing from our perspective as we said -- we look at automated driving and far end of the spectrum and safety. And what excites us most is getting to level 2 automated driving, which is fully commercialize today. You can get to 80% of the active safety benefits, so dare really at a fraction of the cost. And that is really why we're seeing the tremendous demand for active safety solutions. As Joe mentioned in his comments, our active safety revenues grew 70% in the quarter. And we expect from a company growth rate standpoint over the next few years, grow at roughly 50%. And it's that sort of cost benefit analysis that's driving that growth.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Colin Langan from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Colin Langan from UBS.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any color on that cadence of Powertrain margins, as we look at? You mentioned in the commentary there's a 40-basis-point hit from FX. Sure that continue through the year, or should we see these margins start to recover?
componenttext: Any color on that cadence of Powertrain margins, as we look at? You mentioned in the commentary there's a 40-basis-point hit from FX. Sure that continue through the year, or should we see these margins start to recover?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Colin, it's Joe. I think just touched on that. But of the things we are seeing in Powertrain, and it ties into the RMB discussion, the powertrain does have some transactional FX disclosures at least to RMB. And that's basically driven by the fact that our
componenttext: Colin, it's Joe. I think just touched on that. But of the things we are seeing in Powertrain, and it ties into the RMB discussion, the powertrain does have some transactional FX disclosures at least to RMB. And that's basically driven by the fact that our Chinese Powertrain business does import for the heavy-duty diesel business, some of its products from our European and U.K. plants. So there is some transactional FX that impact that business. That's really what's driving that 40 basis points. That's going to be very RMB-dependent. I would say apart from that, we are seeing the margin progression in Powertrain that we would expect to just given the volume increases and our typical levels of expected performance. So it's going to be RMB dependent, and it's very specific to that heavy-duty business in China.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: And current outlook for the year is roughly 25 basis points of margin expansion.

componenttext: Yes, in Powertrain.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just on E&S, I mean, you mentioned in the commentary there's $30 million in launch costs between, I guess, E&S and EEA. I mean, even if it's just half E&S, that's a pretty big margin hit for that segment. Does that -- should we be modelin
componenttext: Got it. And then just on E&S, I mean, you mentioned in the commentary there's $30 million in launch costs between, I guess, E&S and EEA. I mean, even if it's just half E&S, that's a pretty big margin hit for that segment. Does that -- should we be modeling it [indiscernible] pretty significant margin upside in the second half of the year, as that $30 million shrink down in the E&S segment, because that's going to be almost 200 basis points -- maybe [indiscernible] half [ph] in this quarter?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It is a significant piece of the quarter, I agree with that. I think our overall guidance for E&S remains unchanged, that's 25 basis points growth on a full year basis. And our guidance from the beginning of the year has incorporated these launch cos
componenttext: Yes. It is a significant piece of the quarter, I agree with that. I think our overall guidance for E&S remains unchanged, that's 25 basis points growth on a full year basis. And our guidance from the beginning of the year has incorporated these launch costs as I've talked about. We knew these launches were happening. They're not a surprise, if you will. So we factor that into full year margin guidance, so that gives you that 25 basis points expansion on a full year basis is what I would suggest.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: All 3 see it, I would say, if you think about the $75 million of revenue, roughly $40 million,to $45 million of it is in EEA. That's not specific -- it's not totally specific to EEA products. But the EEA being such a large business, picks up what I'll call some of the impact from our other Delphi businesses, particularly E&S losing direct supply, but it's also impacted by some of the indirect and particularly, the GM pull ahead of the plant, the 4 plant shutdown from July to June is impactful to EEA. So EEA is the largest, although it tends to suffer more from indirect than direct. That's the way we think about it.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Adam Jonas from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, everybody. Kevin, a question here, a kind of of high-level. We're hearing a lot of auto executives, and I think yourself included, saying things like the automobile should change more in the next 5 years than in the last 50 years. I think you kind of
componenttext: Hey, everybody. Kevin, a question here, a kind of of high-level. We're hearing a lot of auto executives, and I think yourself included, saying things like the automobile should change more in the next 5 years than in the last 50 years. I think you kind of -- they kind of like high-level agree with that sentiment, right?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't know if it's exactly fine, but I think in general, we're going to see a lot of change.
componenttext: Yes. I don't know if it's exactly fine, but I think in general, we're going to see a lot of change.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If we just take that ostensively like at face value, could that -- one could argue that could mean a 5 or 7 or whatever, that number here -- we're serving with an engineering cycle. That cars on the call, all cars on the road are going to feel like
componenttext: Okay. If we just take that ostensively like at face value, could that -- one could argue that could mean a 5 or 7 or whatever, that number here -- we're serving with an engineering cycle. That cars on the call, all cars on the road are going to feel like they're 50 years old. Now do you see -- I'm just curious where you -- I know you don't have a crystal -- I'm, curious kind of -- if your team at a high-level, from a production capacity and demand planning standpoint, think about the possibility of this super cycle of accelerator plays a demand as -- kind of a buying a new car seen as a lifesaving decision. And as more data comes out about the dangers of human driving unassisted relative to the -- to what's available on the market and the very products you provide, whether there could be a movement and even kind of effort, in Washington even to say, "Listen, we've got to get these deathtraps off the road and accelerate." I'm just curious at a level -- I know it's not quasi-lobby type question, but does that get any airplay with you?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen. I understand your point. I think you're going to see a tremendous amount of change, more digitization, more electrification and quite frankly, safer vehicles. And I'd argue first -- and we don't need to get all the way to fully automated to make t
componenttext: Listen. I understand your point. I think you're going to see a tremendous amount of change, more digitization, more electrification and quite frankly, safer vehicles. And I'd argue first -- and we don't need to get all the way to fully automated to make that happen, right? I mean we can get to the level 2. And unfortunately, governments don't move as quickly as markets do and often times, its citizens and consumers want them to. But it's certainly something that internally we're making sure that we have the capabilities. It's why we bought companies like Ottomatika. It's why we've invested in companies like PureDepth. It's why we have the 40 engineers in Silicon Valley. It's why I'm headed to Israel next week to meet with technology partners there. So it's certainly something that we need to be ready for. And I think the challenge for players like us who have commitments to folks like you and investors -- is how do we strike the balance about making sure that we're perfectly positioned for the future and at the same time, ensuring that we are delivering several financial returns between now and then? And those are the trade-offs that we constantly think about, but obviously, there's more and more focus on software and systems integration and electrification. And there's far more investment in that area. When you look at advanced engineering, for us as a percent of our total engineering, I think we're up 10% or 20%, and a big piece of that is investment software.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, and any of a follow-up then, not just investment in software, but investment in human beings. Can you kind of give a real update of kind of where you're short? I mean we obviously know that competition for talent is brutal, and it goes you overlap w
componenttext: Well, and any of a follow-up then, not just investment in software, but investment in human beings. Can you kind of give a real update of kind of where you're short? I mean we obviously know that competition for talent is brutal, and it goes you overlap way, way beyond traditional auto industry in terms of trying to get the best people in the organization, and competing with all sorts of other techno firms and software firms. But where are you kind of -- where is that net talent battle? Is it getting worse and kind of where -- where do you need people most, either by discipline or geography?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, yes, when you think about it from the most rapid growth, from a engineering standpoint, it's clearly on software and systems, they're 25% of our -- those engineers are 25% of our engineering workforce to date. And I think we expected -- just talke
componenttext: Listen, yes, when you think about it from the most rapid growth, from a engineering standpoint, it's clearly on software and systems, they're 25% of our -- those engineers are 25% of our engineering workforce to date. And I think we expected -- just talked about it at our investor day, close to doubling that number over the next 5 years. And that doesn't mean you need to do it in Silicon Valley. You can do it in places like Bangalore, where we're located in places like Shanghai. We're looking at other locations to actually recruit and put those people. And quite frankly, where it makes sense, we partner with outside service providers and leverage their capabilities. But that's been our biggest focus. To be honest, we haven't had a challenge in getting those people. It's not been a constraint, it's not getting in a way product development or our revenue growth. I think part of that is because of the real interesting things we're doing from an automated drive standpoint, from in infotainment standpoint, from a systems integration standpoint, I think we'll benefit from that. It's clearly something that we're very, very focused on.

componenttext: No. I think let's -- if you just back up [indiscernible] commodities for us is really a discussion around copper, particularly now that we've divested thermal. So we've -- copper pricing continues to move down. We have -- for about 80% of our copper [indiscernible passthrough agreements with our customers, so we are neutral to price but it does impact the revenue line. We passthrough that, the exact pricing. So you see it come down on revenue but there's really no OI impact. So that's all we're talking about here, so as copper prices come down, we do have less revenue, but it's really no -- there's no impact on OI, very minimal impact on OI. And what there is on OI is really just more of a timing than anything else.

componenttext: Sure. Let me go first? Sure. So we've kicked off -- as I said, it's completed, it's in process. So over the next 2 years, we'll see rotation of a couple of significant Western European powertrain plants east, and so more consolidation. So it's really for us, in '16, '17, maybe a little bit of '18 of that, so it's relatively short as it goes from a European restructuring perspective, a relatively short time on it for us to get those plants move.

componenttext: And then David, I'll talk about -- I think today, there are customers that are talking about the integration between cluster and infotainment, there are not any that we're working with they're buying the 2 together as a package. It's headed in that direction. Ultimately, I think we'll get there but we're not there at this point in time.

componenttext: Yes. Listen, I'd tell you, I think the adoption of AEV creates some children. I don't think it's the biggest driver. I think in reality, when you look at it -- we've been talking about it for a, probably the last 12, 24 months. It, is a consumer driven demand item. And as a result, OEs are making sure that they have that capability in their product. And that's what's really driving the demand and continues to drive demand. I tell you continue to accelerate, but I think it's what our OEs need to sell the cars.

componenttext: Yes, Emanuel, I'd tell you -- if I will take a step back and look at things, if we look at the first quarter as an example, and you adjust for FX, we are the top end of our revenue range, we're at the top end of our OI range, and we're certainly at the top end of our EPS range. And I think if you do the same sort of look at our Q2 guidance and adjust it for the Japan earthquake issue, you're in a similar situation. So listen, we feel good about where the market is. The point on Joe's slide, we watch everything, right? And we make sure that we can react to everything. And fortunately, we have a cost structure that's very flexible, that we can move very quickly on. We control all of our joint ventures in China, so we make the tactical as well as the strategic decisions to ramp up or ramp down. So we're in control. And because we're in control, we monitor and react to everything that's out there, and want to be in front of things with versus behind them.
