headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kayla, and I will be y our conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Delphi Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Elena Rosman, Delphi
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Kayla, and I will be y our conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Delphi Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Elena Rosman, Delphi's Vice President of Investor Relations. Elena, you may begin your conference.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, Kayla, and thank you for joining today's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. To follow along with today's presentation, our slides can be found at delphi.com under the Investors section of the website. And consistent w
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, Kayla, and thank you for joining today's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
To follow along with today's presentation, our slides can be found at delphi.com under the Investors section of the website. And consistent with prior calls, today's review of our actual and forecasted financials exclude restructuring and other special items and will address the continuing operations of Delphi. The reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included in the back of today's presentation and the press release. Please see Slide 2 for a disclosure on our forward-looking statements, which reflects Delphi's view of our future financial performance, which may be materially different from our actual performance. 
Joining us today will be Kevin Clark, Delphi's President and CEO; and Joe Massaro, CFO and Senior Vice President. As seen on Slide 3, Kevin will provide an operations update as well as an overview of the quarter, and then Joe will cover the financial results and the 2016 outlook in more detail. 
With that, I would now like to turn the call over to Kevin Clark.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you, Elena. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Before Joe gets into our financial results, I'd like to provide some context around second quarter as well as our outlook for the full year. Beginning with the second quarter highlights
componenttext:
So thank you, Elena. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Before Joe gets into our financial results, I'd like to provide some context around second quarter as well as our outlook for the full year. 
Beginning with the second quarter highlights on Slide 5. To summarize, we had a solid quarter, delivering accelerated revenue and earnings growth. Revenues increased 7%, driven by strong double-digit growth in our Electronics and Safety segment, which had over 40% growth in active safety revenue and high single-digit growth in Electrical Architecture. Powertrain revenues, however, were weaker than expected, principally due to lower heavy-duty and light-duty diesel lines. And we also experienced increased demand volatility with certain key local customers across our segment, impacting our growth in the China market, which we currently believe will continue into the second half of the year. 
Operating income increased to $577 million, and margins expanded to 13.7%, driven by both volume growth and continued cost structure optimization. These increases were partially offset by our continued investment in engineering and information systems to fund growth initiatives as well as some recent manufacturing inefficiencies in our Electrical Architecture segment that we're working through. Joe's going to provide more color on these in a few minutes. 
Earnings per share increased 19% to $1.59 a share. And despite some macro headwinds, we're raising the midpoint of our full year EPS outlook, $0.05 to between $5.95 and $6.05 per share. 
As Joe will discuss in detail later, we're reflecting the changing macro environment in updated customer schedules in our revised outlook for sales and operating income in the back half of the year. We remain disciplined in our allocation of capital, investing in both organic and inorganic growth. And at the same time, we returned $144 million of cash shareholders during the quarter, bringing the year-to-date total to roughly $600 million. 
We also posted strong second quarter bookings of $6.5 billion for a total of $13 billion year-to-date, reflecting awards from both our traditional OEMs as well as newer nontraditional customers. 
In summary, we continue to leverage our business model and remain very focused on execution. 
Slide 6 highlights a few of the assumptions impacting our current outlook starting with the positives on the left. Regulatory trends and consumer demands continue to influence fuel economy, CO2 emissions and vehicle safety standards, driving content per vehicle growth. We continue to experience very strong demand for active safety, infotainment, Gas Direct Injection, Valve Train and power electronic product lines, and increased demand for active safety product has translated into increased interest in our automated driving solution. And several cities such as Singapore, Austin, Columbus and others are investing in automated driving pilots, all in support of the future mobility on-demand, presenting us with even more opportunities for future profitable growth. 
The right side of the chart reflects our current view on the macros, including further currency and commodity headwinds, primarily from the recent devaluation of the sterling and Chinese RMB; increased weakness in the global commercial vehicle market, driven by double-digit declines in North America, more than offsetting growth in the European and Asia markets; and slowing global vehicle production in the second half of the year, particularly in China as well as weaker light-duty diesel volumes in both Europe and the emerging markets. 
In summary, although the macro environment appears to be increasingly challenged, we're confident in our updated outlook for the balance of the year.
Continued strong business bookings are reflected on Slide 7, which, as I mentioned, totaled approximately $13 billion in the second quarter. We did a number of important customer bookings as well as several new platform wins in the quarter, including large contract wins for electrical architecture with GM in North America and with Daimler in Europe; powertrain wins, including [indiscernible] train programs of both Hyundai and General Motors; and engine control [indiscernible] win with VW; and a GDi win with Changhong in China. And the key power electronics win for Electronics and Safety was [indiscernible] in China as well as an active safety win with Audi. 
On the right side of the chart, you'll see a sampling of the customer diversity in our year-to-date bookings, ensuring that we're not dependent on any one customer or any one region or business segment for growth.
Turning to Slide 8. As we discussed previously, our customers are increasingly seeing the need for further electrification of powertrain to close regulatory gap on CO2 emissions and fuel economy. 48-mile hybrids delivered roughly a 70% reduction in CO2 emissions compared to full hybrids and about 30% of the costs. Given our strength in electrical architecture and power electronics, Delphi has a competitive advantage in the intelligent electrification of the vehicle. The increased interest from customers is further validated by the stronger volume projections from industry experts. We are now forecasting 48-volt mile hybrids making up 15% of vehicle production by 2025. That's up from just 10% 6 months ago. 
Now we've been awarded a third customer program since our last update, bringing total 48-volt bookings to roughly $200 million, with the first 2 programs launching with European OEMs in late 2017. In addition, we're presently engaged in discussions with 4 additional major OEMs of potential development programs in this exciting space. 
On Slide 9 are just a few examples of some of our 2016 major program launches. Electronics and Safety revenues are benefiting from infotainment launches on the VWM QB platforms, the Cadillac XC5 and the Chrysler Pacifica and Active Safety launches on the result Phoenix and BMW 5 series as well as power electronics lodges on a number of these platforms, including the Volvo S90. 
Revenue growth on our Electrical Architecture segment is partially driven by program launches in the Daimler E Class, Chrysler Pacifica and the mobile S90. And Powertrain revenues are benefiting from the launch of the small engine on Chevrolets Malibu and Volkswagen 1.4 and 1.6-liter engine platforms. 
Turning to Slide 10. Over the last few years, there's been a lot of focus on active safety and the technologies that support it. As you've heard us say previously, active safety technologies are the building blocks that will ultimately support, saving thousands of lives each year. So that's why active safety is the fastest-growing sector in automotive certainly for Delphi. Customers want it and regulators see the benefit of it. 
During the first half of 2016, we booked $700 million active safety awards, which wins across each geographic region and one [indiscernible] well over $1 billion in active safety bookings for the fourth straight year in a row. 
Now with almost 80% of the safety benefit of Level 4 automation coming from just 20% of the costs at Level 2 automation, we see the near term for demand -- near-term demand, rather, for active safety technologies only growing. As a result, we expect our Active Safety revenues to increase roughly 50% annually over the next few years.
And on Slide 11 is a result of our industry-leading portfolio of active safety and automated driving solutions. We were recently selected by Singapore to develop and implement an end-to-end ecosystem for urban, point-to-point, on-demand, autonomous vehicle service. Delphi will provide a fleet of fully autonomous vehicles, leveraging our proven automated driving platform, including advanced sensors, software and electrical distribution. And we will develop a cloud-based mobility on-demand software suite, opening up new potential autonomous markets for Delphi customers and enabling faster commercialization opportunities. 
Other pilots are planned for cities in North America and Europe, and we expect to make those announcements later this year. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Joe to cover the financials in more detail. Joe?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. And we'll start by covering our second quarter performance and then discuss our outlook for the remainder of 2016. Let's begin on Slide 13 with a snapshot of our second quarter financial performance. As Kevin m
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. And we'll start by covering our second quarter performance and then discuss our outlook for the remainder of 2016. 
Let's begin on Slide 13 with a snapshot of our second quarter financial performance. As Kevin mentioned, we delivered solid revenue and earnings growth in the quarter. Revenue was up 9% or 7% adjusted for currency, commodity, acquisitions and divestitures. Our operating margins expanded 10 basis points to 13.7%, and earnings per share grew 19%. Operating cash flow increased to $575 million, driven by higher earnings levels and improved working capital performance, partially offset by higher restructuring outflows. 
Slide 14 provides greater detail of revenue for the quarter. Starting on the left, we had strong sales growth, including the impact of M&A, driven by HellermannTyton, which contributed approximately $200 million of revenue. The impact from the Japan earthquake was within the range we provided in April. The strengthening U.S. dollar principally against the Chinese RMB and pound and lower copper prices were a drag on revenue in the quarter. 
Moving to the right. South America continues to be very weak. Growth in North America and Europe was strong, driven primarily by our Electrical Architecture and DNS segments. Our adjusted growth in China slowed in the quarter to approximately 5%, reflecting volatility in schedules with certain customers, including SGM and Great Wall. While our overall view of full year China vehicle production growth remains unchanged at approximately 4%, we expect fluctuations in quarterly growth over market rates to continue in the second half of the year.
Turning to operating income. Slide 15 walks the year-over-year change for second quarter. Overall, our operating results were in line with our expectations. Flow-through from volume growth contributed to the margin expansion. HellermannTyton was accretive to earnings, and our integration activities and synergy realizations continue on pace. 
Although we did experience some regional performance challenges in the quarter within North American manufacturing Electrical Architecture, which I'll speak to in a moment, launched costs and ENS moderated in the quarter as expected. 
Also, as Kevin referenced, we see significant opportunities in areas such as active safety, automated driving, infotainment and vehicle electrification and continue to increase investment in these areas.
As always, we continue our relentless focus on optimizing our cost structure, leveraging best cost locations and driving increased efficiencies throughout our organization to fund continued investment innovation and to help offset the impact of the discrete performance challenges that I just noted.
Slide 16 takes us through performance by segment. Electrical Architecture, consistent with our expectations, grew 8% on an adjusted basis. HellermannTyton growth was 10%. As I mentioned, operating margin flow-through in electrical architecture was negatively impacted by manufacturing performance challenges in North America, totaling approximately $20 million. During the quarter, we experienced lower efficiency and higher labor costs associated with the previously planned consolidation of facilities. We expect some level of inefficiency to continue into the second half and have included an additional $30 million in our full year guidance. 
Powertrain revenues were flat year-over-year and short of our expectations. As solid growth in our gas business, GDi grew 50% in the quarter, was offset by lower commercial vehicle volumes in North America, a decline in light-duty diesel schedules in Europe and lower China volumes. 
With respect to light-duty diesel, towards the end of the second quarter, our Powertrain segment experienced a decrease in order levels, impacting both the second quarter and the back half of 2016 across multiple customers. We believe the reduced order levels are primarily related to customers managing down overall diesel inventories in Europe and Asia Pacific. The Powertrain margin decline of approximately 50 basis points was driven by the decline in volumes as well as the foreign exchange transaction impact primarily associated with the devaluation of the RMB and pound. 
As expected, Electronics and Safety organic growth accelerated to 14%, reflecting revenues from program launches completed in late 2015 and earlier this year. 
Growth for the quarter includes a drag of approximately 2% for the mechatronic business. Growth was strong across several product lines, including active safety and infotainment, which grew over 40% and 10% in the quarter, respectively, as well as power electronics, which, although currently a small revenue base, grew significantly in the quarter.
E&S margins expanded 10 basis points to 12.4% on strong volume growth and positive net performance, as launch inefficiencies continued to wane. As noted, we continue to increase investments in key technologies to drive growth in E&S, particularly in active safety, automated driving and infotainment. 
Turning to Slide 17. Earnings came in -- at the high end of our range despite a slightly higher tax rate of 17.4% versus a 17% forecast. EPS growth was driven by increased operating earnings and a favorable impact of a lower share count. We exceeded the midpoint of our guidance by $0.04 per share, including $0.03 from operations and $0.01 improvement from below-the-line items. 
Turning to Slide 18 and the outlook for the remainder of the year. I'd like to walk through the changes to our full year revenue and operating income guidance. 
Starting with revenue on the left. Full year revenues are expected to be $16.25 billion to $16.45 billion, with operating income between $2.15 billion and $2.2 billion. The updated revenue guidance reflects a reduction of $450 million from our previous midpoint, including a $200 million reduction related to FX translation and commodities,  primarily resulting, again, from the weakening Chinese RMB, British pound and lower copper prices. 
Reduced global vehicle production accounts for the remainder of the decrease of $250 million. The lower production volumes reflect our views regarding continued weakness in the CB market, the estimated impact of Brexit and lower light-duty diesel volumes. In addition, include an estimate of lower volumes in China related to certain OEs primarily impacting the Powertrain segment. As a result, at a segment level, we now expect Electrical Architecture adjusted growth of 6%, Powertrain growth of 3% and E&S growth of 14%. E&S and Electrical Architecture will continue to provide strong growth throughout the year for Delphi. Accordingly, we expect our full year adjusted growth rate to be approximately 7% for, reflecting over -- growth over market of roughly 5%. 
The earnings impact of the foreign exchange headwinds and the flow-through on lower volumes, including the lower-performance Electrical Architecture, will be partially offset by continued optimization of our cost structure. In addition to accelerating previously planned restructuring actions, we continue to identify additional opportunities to reduce costs in the second half of the year. 
We expect full year operating margin of 13.3%, a 30 basis points expansion over last year. We have tightened and raised the midpoint of our full year EPS guidance to $5.95 to $6.05, reflecting year-over-year growth of 15% at the midpoint.
Moving to the third quarter. We expect to generate revenues of $3.9 billion to $4 billion. The midpoint reflects further organic growth acceleration to 8%, with continued strong growth in Electronics and Safety and Electrical Architecture. 
We expect operating income in the range of $505 million to $525 million and third quarter earnings per share of $1.38 to $1.44, up approximately 10% at the midpoint. 
Turning to Slide 19. Our capital allocation strategy remains unchanged and is an important lever to enhance shareholder value. On the left, we expect cash flow from operations to grow approximately $1.9 billion, in line with earnings. And the deployment priorities on the right are consistent with our strategy, maintaining a strong balance sheet and investment-grade rating.
We are investing in our business through capital expenditures supporting new program launches, ongoing cost alignment and footprint rotation to best cost countries. We are committed to paying a competitive dividend, and when we have excess cash, we have a track record of returning it to shareholders via share repurchases, as evidenced by the $435 million of repurchases we've already done this year. 
Our full year guidance assumes repurchases for the year of $600 million. And we continue to pursue inorganic growth opportunities that meet our investment criteria and strategic growth objectives, particularly on expansion of our Electrical Architecture platform, active safety and automated driving technologies as well as infotainment and power electronics. 
I'll now turn it over to Kevin for some closing remarks before we open it up to questions.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Wrapping up on Slide 20. We delivered solid performance in the second quarter despite a few challenges. Our financial performance continues to be driven by the relevant safe, green and connected technologies that solved some of our customers'
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Wrapping up on Slide 20. We delivered solid performance in the second quarter despite a few challenges. Our financial performance continues to be driven by the relevant safe, green and connected technologies that solved some of our customers' biggest challenges. While we're confident in our second half outlook, which includes 7% organic growth, roughly 60 basis points of margin expansion and mid-teens EPS growth. We continue to optimize our cost structure while investing in technologies that will drive our future growth. Our year-to-date bookings and commercial developments position us well for continued strong revenue and earnings growth. And as Joe just said, we remain disciplined in our allocation of capital, investing in both organic as well as inorganic growth and returning excess cash shareholders through both share repurchases as well as dividends. Through all of this, we remain focused on executing in a more dynamic macro environment during the back half of this year. 
And with that, we'll now turn it over to the operator to open up the line for questions. Thank you.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Rod Lache from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] 
Our first question comes from the line of Rod Lache from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One is just about the growth outlook. So I think that your prior expectation for Delphi's outperformance versus your weighted average exposures something like 900 basis points in the back half. And now it's -- looks like around 600
componenttext: A couple of questions. One is just about the growth outlook. So I think that your prior expectation for Delphi's outperformance versus your weighted average exposures something like 900 basis points in the back half. And now it's -- looks like around 600 basis points, which is up from the 300 to 400 in the first half. Can you talk a little bit about the bridge a little bit more, the bridge to that number? What, for example, specifically is happening in China? What are some of the specific drivers of that acceleration? If you can just comment on programs that are launching and how meaningful those would be. And lastly, I know it's a long question, but we always get questions about how confident we should be about the growth guidance longer term. You guys have been talking about 8% to 10% as you look out to 2017 and beyond. Is there any reason -- just given some of these variances that we're seeing, is there any reason to reassess that longer-term excess growth assumption?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So why don't I -- it's okay, Joe. I'll start at a high level, and you can [indiscernible] length with the details. I think, listen, as you look at our adjusted outlook for the back half of the year from a growth standpoint, as Joe referenced, there's real
componenttext:
So why don't I -- it's okay, Joe. I'll start at a high level, and you can [indiscernible] length with the details. I think, listen, as you look at our adjusted outlook for the back half of the year from a growth standpoint, as Joe referenced, there's really 3 key companies. One is FX and commodity rates and the translation effect, and Joe quantified that as probably $200 million. Then there's 2 separate pieces on volume. Piece one is effectively lower outlook or lower forecast from IHS and customers for vehicle production across the back half of the year, one. And then specific growth relative to market for us, principally in our Powertrain segment. So I think if you look at growth over market in our E&S segment, I think if you look at growth over market in the architectural segment, quite frankly, the outlook remains unchanged. Where it has it changed somewhat, at least in the near term, is on the Powertrain side. And it's principally being driven by a couple of things: one, light-duty diesel growth, and again, I'll Joe comment on that; much lower commercial vehicle growth; and then when we look at the mix of customers we're on in China, an incremental effect related to growth over market there. 
As we look at the back half of the year and risks related to revenue, I'd tell you, we feel very good about where we stand from a revenue outlook, very good where we stand. And as we head into the back half of the year, we'll reassess each of our businesses in each of the markets and take another view about longer-term outlook for growth. Having said that, I would tell you, if you look at our growth over market for calendar year 2016, even on a revised basis, it's very strong relative to overall vehicle production at 5 points over market. So Joe, I'll let you get to the specifics.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let me just expand a little bit on details. So Kevin mentioned -- of the $450 million, $200 million is FX and commodities. Again, FX translation effects is about 50-50. Commodities, primarily copper, is another $100 million. Of the $250 million,
componenttext: Sure. So let me just expand a little bit on details. So Kevin mentioned -- of the $450 million, $200 million is FX and commodities. Again, FX translation effects is about 50-50. Commodities, primarily copper, is another $100 million. Of the $250 million, right now, we see industry volumes of about $100 million coming out. That's based on updated production information that we have, includes some insight into what folks are thinking from a Brexit perspective and impact on Europe. The remaining $150 million, which will be more of the growth over market impact, the diesel, which is both commercial vehicle and light-duty, is $100 million of that $150 million. And then China, we've adjusted down $50 million. As I mentioned in my script, as Kevin touched on, we have seen customer-specific adjustments to schedules. I would almost refer to them as model-specific adjustments. Some inventory balancing, we think, in the back half of the year. Certainly and primarily in powertrains. Certainly, nowhere at the level of schedule call-down that we saw last year, so this is very different. It's model-specific, it's customer-specific, really concentrated in 2 or 3 customers on a couple of platforms. But we did see...

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Can you just maybe give us a couple of examples of programs that are meaningful to -- you still are experiencing somewhat of an acceleration and outperformance in the back half. Are there are 2 or 3 programs that you can site that could be meaningful
componenttext: Yes. Can you just maybe give us a couple of examples of programs that are meaningful to -- you still are experiencing somewhat of an acceleration and outperformance in the back half. Are there are 2 or 3 programs that you can site that could be meaningful? And then also, at a higher level, Powertrain sounds like a lot of it is there, and organic growth was like 0 in the quarter. Obviously, there's some cyclical headwinds there. There's also other issues, of course, with real-world driving emissions and the cost of complying with the new diesel standards. Are there any changes, longer term, that you think are affecting the market dynamics there in terms of either growth or the competitiveness that would affect Powertrain?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: So why don't you respond to -- why don't you talk about what's some of the launch volume that's driving revenue growth in the back half, and then I can comment on Powertrain.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Ron, and we tried to address this because we know this question's come up before. If we look at the Slide 9 of the deck, particularly the ones on the left-hand side, those are really the platforms that for us in the back half of the year are generat
componenttext: Okay. Ron, and we tried to address this because we know this question's come up before. If we look at the Slide 9 of the deck, particularly the ones on the left-hand side, those are really the platforms that for us in the back half of the year are generating the volume growth. Higher content for us, infotainment, active safety-type products, electrical architecture. So we've got the electrical distribution systems, those products. We've got a couple of examples on it. The VW example, we got the take one of their, but that's actually -- that entire platform that we are on that is launching in the back half of the year, the MQV platform. So for us, that's an important one. That's a big one. And it's across actually all 3 segments. We have content from all 3 segments on that vehicle. So that prices under provide some insight into what we see driving volume in the back half.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the Powertrain side, Rod, our view is, as Joe said today, is it's principally Europe-related European OE. Based on our discussions with those OEs, it appears to be inventory rebalancing at this point in time. It's something we're watching closely.
componenttext: And on the Powertrain side, Rod, our view is, as Joe said today, is it's principally Europe-related European OE. Based on our discussions with those OEs, it appears to be inventory rebalancing at this point in time. It's something we're watching closely. But one thing I want to underscore and get back to, as we all know, governments are focused on whether it's the U.S. or Europe. OEs hitting the revised standards. And to the extent there's less light-duty diesel, there needs to be more Powertrain electrification. And I think over although there may be slide these locations in the near term, over the medium- to long-term, when you look at where we sit from a power electronics standpoint, we cited these facts before, the average CVB on a standard internal combustion engine for Delphi is $300. When you look at 48 full, it's 4x that CVP. On a hybrid, it's 5. On a full EV, it's 7x. And given our product portfolio, we're certainly well positioned. And I think that overall trend is why we're seeing such a significant ramp-up in growth in power electronics, just off of low number is a very high growth rate. But when you look at what the we're seeing from a bookings standpoint, just to give you a data point, the first half of last year, we booked roughly $400 million on power electronics vehicle electrification. In the first half of this year, we're over $1.2 billion. So what we're seeing, stepping back and taking a look at the big picture, is significant ramp-up of demand for powertrain electronics or electrification of the Powertrain, which is good for us.

componenttextpreview: So yes. So GDi, we are seeing it, John. I mentioned GDi growth was over 50% in the quarter. Relatively speaking, that's about a $300 million business, so there's a little bit of it. It's growing fast, and we're very excited about it and it will fill that
componenttext: So yes. So GDi, we are seeing it, John. I mentioned GDi growth was over 50% in the quarter. Relatively speaking, that's about a $300 million business, so there's a little bit of it. It's growing fast, and we're very excited about it and it will fill that hole, but there's going to be somewhat of a timing just as diesel comes down. It's obviously much larger business. But we have seen very strong growth in the second quarter and, quite honestly, expect for your growth in GDi to be a little bit over 50%. So we are seeing that. Restructuring, I would say, we are moving a little bit quicker on restructuring and powertrains. Some of that's opportunistic. I would say, at this point, it still consistent with a footprint rotation from west to east, particularly in Europe, although, as you may recall, that is diesel-focused. Those are diesel facilities that we are consolidating into taking out of Western Europe. There was one last year in France. There's another one this year in Spain, and there's going into Romania. So it is diesel-focused but still consistent with the overall plan.

componenttext: Yes. And listen, John, I think it's important to know that a lot of Dan Ward right now, but our outlook for light-duty diesel, FX adjusted, is it's going to grow. It's going to grow 1% year-over-year versus the prior outlook of roughly 3% year-over-year.

componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, that's a good question. It's something maybe we need to be consistently clear. When we talk about market, we're including commercial vehicle market in our production numbers. And Commercial Vehicle, as you know, is roughly 10% of our total reve
componenttext: Yes -- no, that's a good question. It's something maybe we need to be consistently clear. When we talk about market, we're including commercial vehicle market in our production numbers. And Commercial Vehicle, as you know, is roughly 10% of our total revenues, principally in the Powertrain area. Our outlook, for instance, on the commercial vehicle side is for the global market to be down roughly 3% on a year-over-year basis, with the biggest driver of that low growth or no growth really being the North America market. But it's encompassed in the production numbers that we communicate to you and the growth numbers regarding market that we communicate.

componenttext: Yes. The cash -- it'll be -- that one will pretty much go through this year. That primarily relates to closure of Barcelona and Powertrain in Spain. Payback on those types of plant moves, they do vary, and we tend to see anywhere from 3.5 to 4.5 years. Again, that may sound long, but those are confiscated plants to move. That's one of the reason why they're still there, and they're obviously in Western Europe. So there's a little bit more expense but on Powertrain, European Powertrain plant moves that tends to be the range of payback.

componenttext: Yes. I have a longer-term question. Tied to the 48-volt and electrification move and the kind of where the below-the-line question on tax rates. With the longer-term evolution towards partial hybridization, whether it's 48-volt or [indiscernible] hybrids, you have talked about the 3 to 7x CVP move. But the questions we're getting are a couple things. Basically, it boils down to what are the margins likely to be in that future world? What's the competitive environment, given there are players out there clearly servicing Toyota's needs on the hybrid side? Is it going to be as concentrated and hence maybe as profitable as the Powertrain business has proven to be and especially since a lot of it's wiring and wiring a fair amount of copper price for it?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, when you talk about the entire system, our outlook for this space is margins would be roughly in line with the blended rate between Electrical Architecture and Electronics and Safety because what we're focused on selling, Brian, as we've discussed w
componenttext: Well, when you talk about the entire system, our outlook for this space is margins would be roughly in line with the blended rate between Electrical Architecture and Electronics and Safety because what we're focused on selling, Brian, as we've discussed with you in the past, is really the full system. Obviously, there's a period of time when you ramp up new programs or products like this. There's more investing than there is earning. I can tell you, we've talked about EVs or vehicle electrification for quite a while here. And as you know, there was a point in time where we're investing far more than we were earning. This year, we're at a point where it's a profitable product lines, not quite at the levels that we're at for ES/E/EA today, but certainly on a good track to achieve those [indiscernible]. .

componenttext: And I think, just one addition to that, Brian, is as volumes comes up, we start to see a better fit of material savings and just been able to acquire or procure better. Obviously, as these product lines start up relatively low levels, we don't see that other material performance year-over-year.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is around, given the U.K. referendum results, the sustainability of the [indiscernible] tax rate. I know it's early days. I know there are lots of tax treaties that would need to be renegotiated. But could you just kind of help us th
componenttext: Okay. Second question is around, given the U.K. referendum results, the sustainability of the [indiscernible] tax rate. I know it's early days. I know there are lots of tax treaties that would need to be renegotiated. But could you just kind of help us through the impact of risk factors in terms of remaining EU members trying to tax operations locally, that kind of offset, especially with your move to Eastern Europe, that you might have it with that and just kind of how you're thinking about that?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It is something we are paying close attention to. I think that. I think the [indiscernible], to some extent, has obviously settled after the activity at the end of June. To your point, it is going to take a long time. So there are already a couple o
componenttext: Sure. It is something we are paying close attention to. I think that. I think the [indiscernible], to some extent, has obviously settled after the activity at the end of June. To your point, it is going to take a long time. So there are already a couple of things that we're watching and will be mindful of from a, what I'll call, from a tax structure perspective. Those are primarily around how the European Union and the U.K. interacts or contracts effectively post Brexit. At this point, we don't see anything that materially changes our tax rate. So if, from a tax policy perspective, there aren't any single major drivers that if we were to change now, we would have a material impact of 17% tax rate. Obviously, if new treaties and such are struck, new agreements are reached, particularly if it's punitive to U.K.-based companies, we'll obviously have to evaluate how to either structure around those or look at other alternatives. I would caveat, I think, the one thing that's -- our tax structure is a little bit unique in Europe because even if we are U.K.-based, we have a significant presence in Europe. So it's not necessarily one of the tax structures that's built on, what I'll call, just planning initiatives. We have large physical presence in the U.K. We have large physical presence in Luxembourg. And our structure tends to be built around how we do business in Europe, how we do business in the U.K. versus just one-off planning actions. So that tends to be more substantive and tends to hold up better to tax law changes, i.e. things get [indiscernible] far as such. Right now, we see no risk that answers the question, but kind of at this point, we see no risk at this point for the 17% is now out there that we're looking at same we need to go change it now. But obviously, something we will continue to watch diligently as we go forward.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple for me. Just on the third quarter, it was kind of disproportionately lower than what we expected and consensus did. And the growth rate, obviously, is somewhat subdued in terms of operating income. And I just wanted to kind of get a sense of why
componenttext: A couple for me. Just on the third quarter, it was kind of disproportionately lower than what we expected and consensus did. And the growth rate, obviously, is somewhat subdued in terms of operating income. And I just wanted to kind of get a sense of why that is in 3Q in particular. I mean, I take it as some of the factors just an extension of a few of the items that you highlighted, particularly some of the operational issues, right, the kind of $20 million that becomes $30 million. But maybe just I'll leave it there and see if you can kind of give us the line item so we can better understand that sort of sequential year-on-year move, if you will.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a competition of those. So you're right. The EA performance, the Powertrain revenue, those impact the third quarter a little bit more as you think about the back half of the year than the fourth quarter. We've also got -- we continue to
componenttext: Yes. I think it's a competition of those. So you're right. The EA performance, the Powertrain revenue, those impact the third quarter a little bit more as you think about the back half of the year than the fourth quarter. We've also got -- we continue to launch products in EA and E&S and have -- those are more Q4 launches. So you've got a little bit of the items that are weighing us down or a little bit heavier in Q3, with some additional growth coming in, in the fourth quarter, which is what's giving it that look.

componenttext: Actually, growth over market. So it's a relatively basis, strong growth for the quarter. Operationally, to the point Joe talked about, there's launch causes also in the manufacturing inefficiencies and mix Powertrain relative to our other business from a market standpoint.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just related to that, the impact of the supply issue in Japan, you said it came in kind of in line with what you expected and was supposed sort of be made up with 4 in the back half. Maybe can we just put some numbers around that and remind us
componenttext: Got it. And just related to that, the impact of the supply issue in Japan, you said it came in kind of in line with what you expected and was supposed sort of be made up with 4 in the back half. Maybe can we just put some numbers around that and remind us what you're thinking there?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the impact in Q2 was about $40 million to $50 million. We had $50 million as the bottom of our range, so we're basically at the bottom end of the range. I think as you think about it in the back half of the year, it's a little bit of a mixed bag.
componenttext: Yes. So the impact in Q2 was about $40 million to $50 million. We had $50 million as the bottom of our range, so we're basically at the bottom end of the range. I think as you think about it in the back half of the year, it's a little bit of a mixed bag. The way I think about it is we called off revenue of about $100 million from an industry volume perspective in the back half of the year. The Japan impact or the recovery of that is effectively netted in there, and it's case-by-case. Some customers, you clearly saw come back. Others talked about it, not coming back, but maybe as it related to some of the other inventory adjustments. So less of an impact in Q2 and effectively netted within our industry volume adjustment in the back half of the year.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I can just ask one maybe more theoretical or longer-term question. On Slide 11, from this announcement, interesting when you made it. Is there -- I mean, you mentioned Columbus, Ohio I think, the Smart City challenge winner in Boston, I thi
componenttext: Got it. And if I can just ask one maybe more theoretical or longer-term question. On Slide 11, from this announcement, interesting when you made it. Is there -- I mean, you mentioned Columbus, Ohio I think, the Smart City challenge winner in Boston, I think. Is there anybody doing kind of robot taxi like Singapore? I mean, when we've looked at it, it seems like most municipalities are just starting with kind of some kind of an automated bus or shuttle system, and Singapore seems to be, by far, the most ambitious. But you guys having kind of build delved into it a lot more deeply. Wanted to see if that's what you were seeing as well.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Singapore is the most advanced from a plan to get to, use your term, robot taxis. And we've been working with them or playing with them for about the past year. There are several other cities that are talking about it at this point in time, that we'r
componenttext: Yes. Singapore is the most advanced from a plan to get to, use your term, robot taxis. And we've been working with them or playing with them for about the past year. There are several other cities that are talking about it at this point in time, that we're talking with, providing the same sort of service and solution. But when you look at Singapore in terms of actually executing, we're in a situation now where we've launched the program. We'll have pilotless vehicles for 2 years through the end of 2018 and actually pilot those vehicles beginning in 2019. And their plan is to have pilotless vehicles, a fleet of pilotless vehicle in the area that we're currently testing beyond 2020 servicing consumers. So they, by far, are aware some that we look at other U.S. cities, they are certainly are examples. One is talking about it. Amsterdam is talking about it. They're looking at it and where we're located in outside of Shanghai and [indiscernible]. So there's a lot of dialogue, but Singapore's first.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Leiker with Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Leiker with Baird.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I wanted to touch on, I guess, 2 things. One is on the 48-volt launches that you have coming up in the contract, the bookings that you have. Are these bookings that go into vehicles, that are meant to be a small portion of the fleet kind of test ty
componenttext: Kevin, I wanted to touch on, I guess, 2 things. One is on the 48-volt launches that you have coming up in the contract, the bookings that you have. Are these bookings that go into vehicles, that are meant to be a small portion of the fleet kind of test type applications? Or are they broader in scale, where the entire vehicle platform may end up being a 48-volt?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I think it's ultimately entire vehicle platform. It's lower volume today. So as I mentioned to you, we have, through the second quarter, $200 million of total bookings, including those 2 programs that are going to launch next year with Europe
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I think it's ultimately entire vehicle platform. It's lower volume today. So as I mentioned to you, we have, through the second quarter, $200 million of total bookings, including those 2 programs that are going to launch next year with European OEs. But they're launching on vehicles that tend to have a significant amount of volume. So I wouldn't -- I'd call it beyond a test, but it's certainly not high-volume in this case. And when you go through the economics and the discussions that we're having with -- when you go -- based on the discussions we're having with the other OEs at this point in time and you talk about the technology, the cost the technology and the fashion of the technology, we think this is something that is going to gain significant traction, as do those OEs.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The economics make a lot of sense there. And then on the autonomous driving side. There's been discussion here in the last few weeks of trying to create some industry standards for the sensor suite algorithms, the applications to accelerate the path throu
componenttext: The economics make a lot of sense there. And then on the autonomous driving side. There's been discussion here in the last few weeks of trying to create some industry standards for the sensor suite algorithms, the applications to accelerate the path through regulations, through development and ultimately lower the cost curve on that. What's Delphi's view on that and your ability to participate in something along those lines?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, listen, ultimately, if you were to break the market down in 2 spaces, if you're looking at the mobility providers, the nontraditional OEs, I think they are less focused on the standard, and they are less price-sensitive. For them, it's about the eco
componenttext: Well, listen, ultimately, if you were to break the market down in 2 spaces, if you're looking at the mobility providers, the nontraditional OEs, I think they are less focused on the standard, and they are less price-sensitive. For them, it's about the economics of drivers and more vehicles. So it's a slightly different answer. But I think, for the traditional OEs, having a standard makes significant sense. And it's, to your point, what will drive down costs and ultimately will drive up penetration. And our view is with some of the recent events and certainly the dialogue out of Washington, that's something you're going to see more pressure on or greater push towards.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And where do you see Delphi? Are you part of a group that drives that? Do you take the baton and drive that effort to standardization? What's your role?
componenttext: And where do you see Delphi? Are you part of a group that drives that? Do you take the baton and drive that effort to standardization? What's your role?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When you look at the suite of products we have, from both hardware to software as well as some of the partnerships that we have, we think we're ideally positioned with support, quite frankly, from others to actually be one of the leaders in supply su
componenttext: Yes. When you look at the suite of products we have, from both hardware to software as well as some of the partnerships that we have, we think we're ideally positioned with support, quite frankly, from others to actually be one of the leaders in supply supply-based driving now.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: What is your outlook for the Chinese government tax incentives on smaller engine vehicles? Do you presume in your forecast that this goes away at the end of the year or it is extended? And if you presume it goes away, does it provide any sort of bump in the fourth quarter on like prebuy?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point, we've assumed that it is as much of a 2017 question. We assume it ends just, for lack of any better information. I would tell you, we have had some discussions internally about prebuys. Haven't necessarily seen the big portion of customer s
componenttext: At this point, we've assumed that it is as much of a 2017 question. We assume it ends just, for lack of any better information. I would tell you, we have had some discussions internally about prebuys. Haven't necessarily seen the big portion of customer schedules perspective yet. It's not too late to flow some of that. China has got to be, just from a year-over-year comp perspective, a little interesting for everyone. That's not is for everyone in Q3, Q4 just given the volatility from last year. And last Q4 was, obviously, a strong quarter in China. But at this point, assuming it ends at the end of the year and have yet to see any big discernible pull as a result of an ending.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then the last question is just on the M&A environment. You mentioned the prepared remarks that you continue to pursue inorganic growth opportunities that meet your investment criteria. So I'm curious what the environment looks like the ability to tr
componenttext: Okay. Then the last question is just on the M&A environment. You mentioned the prepared remarks that you continue to pursue inorganic growth opportunities that meet your investment criteria. So I'm curious what the environment looks like the ability to track attractive prices presently the company's are out there. But relative to attractive prices how to think about that because you know the stock market is at an all-time record high and yet the prices in multiple for automotive companies are so down. So what's the more important metric the valuation of the market overall if you're going to buy technology-type company or the evaluation of automotive companies?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Brian, I think each situation is unique. When you look at the high-tech companies, you're right, you certainly have seen valuations increase. That's probably why Joe and his team are focusing on investment opportunities out of Silicon Valley. Actual
componenttext: Well, Brian, I think each situation is unique. When you look at the high-tech companies, you're right, you certainly have seen valuations increase. That's probably why Joe and his team are focusing on investment opportunities out of Silicon Valley. Actually, doing more activity outside of Silicon Valley from a prospecting standpoint, and we'll probably talk about more about that later this year. From a more traditional acquisition standpoint, listen, we have a fairly simple and straightforward perspective, and it's really cash-on-cash return. We look at those as traditional cash flow investments, and they need to generate the right return on invested capital for us to go forward to make those investments, including both purchase price, certainly, on the outflow. But when you look at performance of the business, margin expansion opportunities and synergies.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Colin Langan with UBS.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Just on a follow-up on the Singapore fleet. Any color on how these vehicles would work? I mean, are they going to be geographically range-bound, limited in terms of crude? Any fleet restrictions are they working on whether [indiscernible] just kind of curious to see if this will be deployed initially.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, they will be geographically range-bound. There's an area called One North, which is about 5 square miles, 5-square-mile space where they will be residential and commercial. As I mentioned, for the first 2 years of the program beginning now, we a
componenttext: Yes. Yes, they will be geographically range-bound. There's an area called One North, which is about 5 square miles, 5-square-mile space where they will be residential and commercial. As I mentioned, for the first 2 years of the program beginning now, we actually have a vehicle there now. We'll have 6 vehicles there by the end of next year. For what [indiscernible] 5 [ph], which will be fully electric vehicles. They'll be piloted for 2 years, and then they will be pilotless beginning in year 3. And they'll operate in and around that range.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And on the 48-volt technology, how is your technology different from your peers? Do you think, particularly on the vehicles that you are launching on, did you need the partner, things like battery and motor or the OEM kind of find those components
componenttext: Got it. And on the 48-volt technology, how is your technology different from your peers? Do you think, particularly on the vehicles that you are launching on, did you need the partner, things like battery and motor or the OEM kind of find those components on their own? And overall, do you think this has any impact on the full EV demand and like prebuyable bridge fuel economy [indiscernible]?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, our outlook, when you look at our outlook for the market for HEV, EV, by 2025, we're still -- our perspective is they make up high teens percentage of overall vehicle production, with full electrics representing roughly 2% to 3% and 48-volt r
componenttext: Yes. I mean, our outlook, when you look at our outlook for the market for HEV, EV, by 2025, we're still -- our perspective is they make up high teens percentage of overall vehicle production, with full electrics representing roughly 2% to 3% and 48-volt representing roughly 15% of the vehicle production, which, 6 months ago, the IHS outlook was that they were 10 points of that worth. When you look at the economics, it's a no-brainer, quite frankly. When you look at what Delphi brings to the party, in addition to systems integration, from a product standpoint, we bring everything with the exception of the e-motor, the e-turbo and battery. And the solution that we're offering, we're partnering with others to offer those solutions to OEs. And it would be our intention longer-term to continue to partner with third parties versus development internal capabilities in those areas.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joseph Spak from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you just help me a little bit more with the fourth quarter margin year-over-year bridge because if my math's right, you're pointing to something like about like 13.9%. And I know, on a year-ago period, you would build with all the ineff
componenttext: I was wondering if you just help me a little bit more with the fourth quarter margin year-over-year bridge because if my math's right, you're pointing to something like about like 13.9%. And I know, on a year-ago period, you would build with all the inefficiencies in China from the rapid ramp-up. But it also sounds like you're talking about some continued inefficiencies in the back half. so I was just wondering if I'm missing anything else big that helps bridge that improvement.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think if you think about -- you have the right components. So we had inefficiencies, $25 million to $30 million last year in China as we dealt with the Windsor on the volume ramp. That's obviously not there. That comes out. We will see a bit of an e
componenttext: No. I think if you think about -- you have the right components. So we had inefficiencies, $25 million to $30 million last year in China as we dealt with the Windsor on the volume ramp. That's obviously not there. That comes out. We will see a bit of an efficiency, the current E/EA inefficiencies in North America. We'll see those wind down over the course of the quarter so think of that as roughly $10 million in the fourth quarter. Fourth quarter is usually strong for us. Fourth quarter's usually strong for us as well remember as we have NRE, and we have nonrecurring engineering. We get a lot of our reimbursements in the fourth quarter, particularly in the E&S and Powertrain business. So that margin rate is typically stronger in the fourth quarter as a result of that, and we continue to see that and call that $20 million or so if you want to range-bound it.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Joe -- having been around a little bit longer than Joe, if you go back and look at '14 versus '13 fourth quarter and so on and so forth, you'll know fourth quarter margins tend to be our highest. It's for the reason that Joe has talked about. So
componenttext: I think, Joe -- having been around a little bit longer than Joe, if you go back and look at '14 versus '13 fourth quarter and so on and so forth, you'll know fourth quarter margins tend to be our highest. It's for the reason that Joe has talked about. So it's really in line on a more normalized comparison.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. Can you just remind me what the $25 million to $30 million in inefficiencies in China last year, was that mostly in Powertrain? Or where did that -- how does that break down? .
componenttext: Correct. Can you just remind me what the $25 million to $30 million in inefficiencies in China last year, was that mostly in Powertrain? Or where did that -- how does that break down? .

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mostly in Electrical Architecture.
componenttext: Mostly in Electrical Architecture.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Electrical Architecture. Okay. Just quickly on the Singapore deal, I guess, it was just like it seems like the straw's heavily on maybe the automatic acquisition. I was wondering if there's a little bit of a change in strategy with that asset or you're go
componenttext: Electrical Architecture. Okay. Just quickly on the Singapore deal, I guess, it was just like it seems like the straw's heavily on maybe the automatic acquisition. I was wondering if there's a little bit of a change in strategy with that asset or you're going more after the sort of shared mobility concept versus potentially sign that to OEs or seem to be on the margin wanting to maybe a little bit more work in house. And then how -- for this, A, is that true? And then B, for this deal, how does the OE or other partners get involved in this like I guess why do they come to you as the first point of entry?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they came to us because we provide the full suite of services, and they were less focused on what type of vehicle we're actually using. So the vehicle there right there right now is actually -- it's another Audi SKU Q5. The additional 5 vehicles tha
componenttext: Well, they came to us because we provide the full suite of services, and they were less focused on what type of vehicle we're actually using. So the vehicle there right there right now is actually -- it's another Audi SKU Q5. The additional 5 vehicles that we're going to select is a choice between 2 OEs. And I don't want to get into that but it will be fully electric. And they are really focused less on the carbon, but how does the overall system were? Not only the vehicle, but also how does the vehicle interact from an infrastructure standpoint? And how do we put a cloud-based system in that allows the government of Singapore to operate a mobility on-demand service, okay? So it goes above and beyond that so that they can drop that service in. I would say that's an expansion of what we've previously contemplated. We think there's a lot they will learn. There's a lot we will learn. I think the mobility on-demand quite frankly what you're seeing is a space of the market moving much faster to get automated driving than the traditional OEs. And although all the traditional are focused on it, and as you know, some are further along than others. When you look at the nontraditional players out there in the mobility space, they're moving much more aggressively, much faster, and it seems to be a bigger priority. And we want to be a part of that. We want to be one of the first movers in that.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to assume that the automatic has shifted a little bit towards providing that type of solution versus trying to sort of position that more to OEs for owned autonomy, if you will?
componenttext: Is it fair to assume that the automatic has shifted a little bit towards providing that type of solution versus trying to sort of position that more to OEs for owned autonomy, if you will?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Listen, I think -- I don't think the strategy has changed at all. I guess, given the pace of change and the desire to move quickly, that the mobility providers and nontraditional folks out there are looking to ramp it up faster and, therefore, are mor
componenttext: No. Listen, I think -- I don't think the strategy has changed at all. I guess, given the pace of change and the desire to move quickly, that the mobility providers and nontraditional folks out there are looking to ramp it up faster and, therefore, are more interested in that part of automatic that we have to offer. The traditional OEs, there are some that we're working with or providing automatic algorithms to. There are others, to your point, that are developing their own.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then recent news this morning, Samsung and the ready discussions there. How would that impact your infotainment business from a competitive standpoint? And then secondly, when you guys consider selling off infotainment if -- obviously, if the
componenttext: Got you. And then recent news this morning, Samsung and the ready discussions there. How would that impact your infotainment business from a competitive standpoint? And then secondly, when you guys consider selling off infotainment if -- obviously, if there was the right price for it?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start with the last, and then we can respond to the first. Listen, our infotainment business, we consider to be very strategic. Joe talked about the growth rates. It's going to grow close to 20% this year, and I think it accelerates to 2017 a
componenttext: Well, let me start with the last, and then we can respond to the first. Listen, our infotainment business, we consider to be very strategic. Joe talked about the growth rates. It's going to grow close to 20% this year, and I think it accelerates to 2017 and beyond. So it's a great space, and we think it's a great space to convergence between active safety, infotainment, cluster technology. We're starting to see that today, and we think we got a great position in it. Having said that, we are about how do we maximize return to shareholders, right? And from that perspective, I guess, I would never say never, but I think it's highly unlikely based on what we view the opportunities to be in that space. With respect to the story today about Samsung and McNulty, listen, we're very familiar with both companies. And if that were something to happen, it's not something that we're overly concerned about.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Emmanuel Rosner from CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Emmanuel Rosner from CLSA.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first, a quick point of clarification on China and sort of the issues you're seeing automakers in the Powertrain business. When you look sort of like the full year outlook by now, I think, up until now, you sort of expect it to outperform the market
componenttext: Just first, a quick point of clarification on China and sort of the issues you're seeing automakers in the Powertrain business. When you look sort of like the full year outlook by now, I think, up until now, you sort of expect it to outperform the market quite a bit. What is sort of your outlook for full year, your own full year China revenue in comparison to the market now?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're, right now, looking at full year China growth of 9%, adjusted growth of 9%. As I mentioned, we have a view of China production growth of about 4% or 5% of the market on the full year. Again, there will be some bouncing around in Q3 and Q4 wi
componenttext: Yes. So we're, right now, looking at full year China growth of 9%, adjusted growth of 9%. As I mentioned, we have a view of China production growth of about 4% or 5% of the market on the full year. Again, there will be some bouncing around in Q3 and Q4 with those rates, obviously, just given what happened last year and just the comparables year-over-year. But for full year, when it settles, 9% growth and about 5% of the market.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, just shifting to the ADAS opportunity. Obviously, significant content opportunity over time. At the same time, a lot of the sort of components seem to be in the becoming significantly cheaper very quickly. And then, obvi
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, just shifting to the ADAS opportunity. Obviously, significant content opportunity over time. At the same time, a lot of the sort of components seem to be in the becoming significantly cheaper very quickly. And then, obviously, a lot of it has to do with ramping up volume. What is sort of the environment you're seeing in terms of price progression for active safety content and component? And is that still -- in terms of getting that to sort of reasonable margin, is that still consistent with it?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our price outlook hasn't changed. We still think around 2% is the right number for Delphi overall. We actually -- we're a little lower than that in Q2. You're right, electronics and Safety tends to be our one segment where our prices are a little bit
componenttext: Yes. Our price outlook hasn't changed. We still think around 2% is the right number for Delphi overall. We actually -- we're a little lower than that in Q2. You're right, electronics and Safety tends to be our one segment where our prices are a little bit higher, 2.5 to 2.5 to 3. But again, we are comfortable with that range. Don't see things significantly changing. And as I mentioned, one benefit that we do see the margin over time and expect to continue to see as these newer product lines grow in volume, material savings also becomes more available to us. So as we buy more, we're able to leverage that spend better. A product line at $100 million, there's only so much leverage you can do. As these get to $0.5 billion and beyond, there's obviously more leverage over the supply base.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Emmanuel, if I can add, I mean, we're now at a point, we've talked previously -- we talked about specifically the active safety about in investing mode. We're in profit mode now. It's not we're in of E&S margins are but we are clearly making money. I
componenttext: Yes. Emmanuel, if I can add, I mean, we're now at a point, we've talked previously -- we talked about specifically the active safety about in investing mode. We're in profit mode now. It's not we're in of E&S margins are but we are clearly making money. I think it was respect to price pressure with, specifically as it relates to active safety, it really somewhat depends on what sort of active safety solution you're talking about, right? If it's Level 1 where it's just the camera or just a radar, right, that, as you know, an industry that commoditize is it's a very. And to Joe's point, we are really getting crosstalk when we get volume and leveraging the manufacturing plant as well as hitting material savings. As you get into integrated solution where you're fusing sensors, that's a much different scenario. And there are only a few players that can actually do that, we being one of them. And I think in those sort of scenarios, and that's where the space is headed, in those sort of scenarios, the pricing pressure is actually very reasonable. It's there. I mean, it's always there, but it's much more reasonable.

With respect to growth over market, that's something we're still working through. I would think it's roughly in line with what we're seeing this year or more, depending on what we see in terms of acceleration in active safety, infotainment, power electronics, all the areas that Joe just talked about.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is, you're competing with some very formidable competitors whether it of the active safety or connectivity or autonomous driving vehicles and so forth. My question is, does the fact that you have an Electrical Architectu
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is, you're competing with some very formidable competitors whether it of the active safety or connectivity or autonomous driving vehicles and so forth. My question is, does the fact that you have an Electrical Architecture business give you an advantage? Or is it more along the lines averts a separate business that just is growing as vehicles are electrifying? I guess, I'm wondering if there's synergies between that and the other portions of your business that maybe gives you a leg up versus, let's say, a Bosch or a [indiscernible], somebody else along those lines?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I mean, to your point, they're terrific competitors. They have great technology, as do we. But having electrical architecture that really enables, right, it's an enabler of everything that we're talking about, whether it's active safety, auto
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I mean, to your point, they're terrific competitors. They have great technology, as do we. But having electrical architecture that really enables, right, it's an enabler of everything that we're talking about, whether it's active safety, automated driving or vehicle electrification, electrification of the Powertrain and having the ability to combine that know-how with what we know in E&S and Powertrain and areas, for example, like [indiscernible], which we're doing for VW, combining those capabilities is significant. We're looking at similar opportunities from a technology standpoint as it relates to infotainment and clusters. So having that capability and the ability to take out costs and take out complexity based on our experience in that segment is huge.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I think, Kevin mentioned earlier, I think 48 volts is another example of that. If you think of we have to partner on the motor, the e-turbo and the battery but the rest of the content that 48 motor vehicle, is Delphi content. And without the electrical architecture business, it would obviously not be possible for that system together at that level. So that's vehicle electrification. Everyone where both the Powertrain business and the EA are able to collaborate benefits.

componenttext: It's more than one customer. It's, call it, 4 customers. I do think there is some consistency in what we're seeing across those customers. They are -- and we've talked to each of them, and we're obviously engaged. That message back from them has a consistency of exactly what I have said, which is managing diesel inventories, heading into summer shutdowns for the back half of the year. And we're dealing with primarily European production, although there is some export to Asia Pac/India that we're seeing impacted as well. So again, hard broader conclusion in that. We are certainly not at this point where we've had very specific dialogues with the customers. But it is more than one month. It isn't just one customer.

componenttext: If I could augment Joe's comment. Listen, the commercial vehicle side, it straight market. It ended up being a very challenging market for anyone in that space. So to Joe's points, listen, we're seeing some dots. We're trying to connect the dots. They all may not be perfectly correlated because each OE has a different inventory levels, quite frankly, has different mix of vehicles and those all come in to play. So at times, and a different point in time, recent challenging calculus to give you a real specific answer.
