headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I think it's ultimately entire vehicle platform. It's lower volume today. So as I mentioned to you, we have, through the second quarter, $200 million of total bookings, including those 2 programs that are going to launch next year with Europe
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I think it's ultimately entire vehicle platform. It's lower volume today. So as I mentioned to you, we have, through the second quarter, $200 million of total bookings, including those 2 programs that are going to launch next year with European OEs. But they're launching on vehicles that tend to have a significant amount of volume. So I wouldn't -- I'd call it beyond a test, but it certainly is not high-volume in this case. And when you go through the economics and the discussions that we're having with -- when you go -- based on the discussions we're having with the other OEs at this point in time, and you talk about the technology, the cost of the technology and benefit of the technology, we think this is something that is going to gain significant traction, as do those OEs.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The economics make a lot of sense there. And then on the autonomous driving side. There's been discussion here in the last few weeks of trying to create some industry standards for the sensor suite, the algorithms, the applications to accelerate the path
componenttext: The economics make a lot of sense there. And then on the autonomous driving side. There's been discussion here in the last few weeks of trying to create some industry standards for the sensor suite, the algorithms, the applications to accelerate the path through regulations, through development and ultimately lower the cost curve on that. What's Delphi's view on that and your ability to participate in something along those lines?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, listen, ultimately, if you were to break the market down into 2 spaces, if you look at the mobility providers, the nontraditional OEs, I think they're less focused on a standard, and they're less price-sensitive. For them, it's about the economics o
componenttext: Well, listen, ultimately, if you were to break the market down into 2 spaces, if you look at the mobility providers, the nontraditional OEs, I think they're less focused on a standard, and they're less price-sensitive. For them, it's about the economics of drivers and more vehicles. So it's a slightly different answer. But I think, for the traditional OEs, having a standard makes significant sense. And it's, to your point, what will drive down costs and ultimately will drive up penetration. And our view is, with some of the recent events and certainly the dialogues out of Washington, that's something you're going to see more pressure on or greater push towards.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And where do you see Delphi? Are you part of a group that drives that? Do you take the baton and drive that effort to standardization? What's your role?
componenttext: And where do you see Delphi? Are you part of a group that drives that? Do you take the baton and drive that effort to standardization? What's your role?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when you look at the suite of products we have, from both hardware to software as well as some of the partnerships that we have, we think we're ideally positioned with support, quite frankly, from others to actually be one of the leaders in supply-ba
componenttext: Yes, when you look at the suite of products we have, from both hardware to software as well as some of the partnerships that we have, we think we're ideally positioned with support, quite frankly, from others to actually be one of the leaders in supply-based driving now.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Brinkman from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Brinkman from JPMorgan.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: What is your outlook for the Chinese government tax incentives on smaller-engine vehicles? Do you presume in your forecast that this goes away at the end of the year or that it is extended? And if you presume it goes away, does it provide any sort of a bu
componenttext: What is your outlook for the Chinese government tax incentives on smaller-engine vehicles? Do you presume in your forecast that this goes away at the end of the year or that it is extended? And if you presume it goes away, does it provide any sort of a bump in the fourth quarter on like prebuy?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point, we've assumed that -- and this is as much a 2017 question, we assume it ends, just for lack of any better information. I would tell you, they're having -- we have had some discussions internally about prebuys, haven't necessarily seen a big
componenttext: At this point, we've assumed that -- and this is as much a 2017 question, we assume it ends, just for lack of any better information. I would tell you, they're having -- we have had some discussions internally about prebuys, haven't necessarily seen a big push from customer schedules perspective yet. It's not too late to flow some of that. China is got to be, just from a year-over-year comp perspective, a little interesting for everyone, not just us, for everyone in Q3, Q4 just given the volatility from last year. And last Q4 was, obviously, a very strong quarter in China. But at this point, assuming it ends at the end of the year and have yet to see any big discernible pull as a result of an ending.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then the last question is just on the M&A environment. You mentioned in the prepared remarks that you continue to pursue inorganic growth opportunities that meet your investment criteria. So I'm curious what the environment looks like, the ability t
componenttext: Okay. Then the last question is just on the M&A environment. You mentioned in the prepared remarks that you continue to pursue inorganic growth opportunities that meet your investment criteria. So I'm curious what the environment looks like, the ability to find attractive companies at attractive prices. Presumably, the companies are out there, but relative to attractive prices, how do you think about that? Because the stock market is at an all-time record high and yet the prices in multiple for automotive companies are so down. So what's the more important metric, the valuation of the market overall, if you're going to buy a technology-type company, or the valuation of automotive companies?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, listen Brian, I think each situation is unique. When you look at the high-tech companies, you're right, you certainly have seen valuations increase. That's probably why Joe and his team are in addition [ph] to focus -- focusing on investment opportu
componenttext: Well, listen Brian, I think each situation is unique. When you look at the high-tech companies, you're right, you certainly have seen valuations increase. That's probably why Joe and his team are in addition [ph] to focus -- focusing on investment opportunities out of Silicon Valley. Actually, doing more activity outside of Silicon Valley from a prospecting standpoint, and we'll probably talk about more about that later this year. From a more traditional acquisition standpoint, listen, we have a fairly simple and straightforward perspective, and it's really cash-on-cash return. We look at those as traditional cash flow investments, and they need to generate the right return on invested capital for us to go forward to make those investments, including both purchase price, certainly, on the outflow, but when you look at performance of the business, margin expansion opportunities and synergies.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Colin Langan from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Colin Langan from UBS.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on a follow-up on the Singapore fleet any color on how these vehicles would work? I mean, are they going to be geographically range-bound, limited to certain routes? Any fleet restrictions? Will they work on all weather? Just kind of curious how thes
componenttext: Just on a follow-up on the Singapore fleet any color on how these vehicles would work? I mean, are they going to be geographically range-bound, limited to certain routes? Any fleet restrictions? Will they work on all weather? Just kind of curious how these will be deployed initially.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, they will be geographically range-bound. There's an area called One North, which is about 5 square miles, 5-square-mile space where they will be resident to its residential and commercial. As I mentioned, for the first 2 years of the program, be
componenttext: Yes. Yes, they will be geographically range-bound. There's an area called One North, which is about 5 square miles, 5-square-mile space where they will be resident to its residential and commercial. As I mentioned, for the first 2 years of the program, beginning now, we actually have a vehicle there now. We'll have 6 vehicles there by the end of next year. For what it's worth 5 of which will be fully electric vehicles. They'll be piloted for 2 years, and then they will be pilotless beginning in year 3. And they'll operate in and around that range.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And on the 48-volt technology, how is your technology different from your peers? Do you think, particularly, on the vehicles that you are launching on, did you need to partner, things like battery and e-motor, or the OEMs kind of find those compon
componenttext: Got it. And on the 48-volt technology, how is your technology different from your peers? Do you think, particularly, on the vehicles that you are launching on, did you need to partner, things like battery and e-motor, or the OEMs kind of find those components on their own? And overall, do you think this has any impact on the full EV demand, it seems like a pretty viable bridge to fuel economy at a [indiscernible].

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, our outlook, when you look at our outlook for the market for HEV, EV, by 2025, we're still -- our perspective is they make up high-teens percentage of overall vehicle production, with full electrics representing roughly 2% to 3% and 48-volt r
componenttext: Yes, I mean, our outlook, when you look at our outlook for the market for HEV, EV, by 2025, we're still -- our perspective is they make up high-teens percentage of overall vehicle production, with full electrics representing roughly 2% to 3% and 48-volt representing roughly 15% of the vehicle production, which, 6 months ago, the IHS outlook was that they were worth 10 points of that growth. When you look at the economics, it's a no-brainer, quite frankly. When you look at what Delphi brings to the party, in addition to systems integration, from a product standpoint, we bring everything with the exception of the e-motor, the e-turbo and battery. And the solution that we're offering, we're partnering with others to offer those solutions to OEs. And it would be our intention, longer term, to continue to partner with third parties versus development internal capabilities in those areas.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joseph Spak from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joseph Spak from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just help me a little bit more with the fourth quarter margin year-over-year bridge because if my math's right, you're pointing to something like about like 13.9%. And I know, on the year-ago period, you dealt with all the ine
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just help me a little bit more with the fourth quarter margin year-over-year bridge because if my math's right, you're pointing to something like about like 13.9%. And I know, on the year-ago period, you dealt with all the inefficiencies in China from the rapid ramp-up. But it also sounds like you're talking about some continued inefficiencies in the back half. So I was just wondering if I'm missing anything else big that helps bridge that improvement.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think you think about -- you have the right components. So we had inefficiencies, $25 million to $30 million last year in China as we dealt with the whipsaw on the volume ramp. That's obviously not there. That comes out. We will see a little bit of
componenttext: No. I think you think about -- you have the right components. So we had inefficiencies, $25 million to $30 million last year in China as we dealt with the whipsaw on the volume ramp. That's obviously not there. That comes out. We will see a little bit of inefficiency, the current E/EA inefficiencies in North America, we'll see those wind down over the course of the quarter, so think of that as roughly $10 million in the fourth quarter. Fourth quarter is usually strong for us. Fourth quarter is usually strong for us as well, remember, as we have NRE, and we have nonrecurring engineering. We got a lot of our reimbursements in the fourth quarter, particularly in the E&S and Powertrain business. So that margin rate is typically stronger in the fourth quarter as a result of that, and we continue to see that and call that $20 million or so if you wanted to range-bound it.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Joe, having been around a little bit longer than Joe, if you go back and look at '14 versus '13 fourth quarter, so on and so forth, you'll know, fourth quarter margins tend to be our highest. It's for the reasons that Joe has talked about. So it'
componenttext: I think, Joe, having been around a little bit longer than Joe, if you go back and look at '14 versus '13 fourth quarter, so on and so forth, you'll know, fourth quarter margins tend to be our highest. It's for the reasons that Joe has talked about. So it's really in line on a more normalized comparison.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you just remind me what the $25 million to $30 million in inefficiencies in China last year, is that mostly in Powertrain? Or where did that -- how did that break down?
componenttext: Okay. Can you just remind me what the $25 million to $30 million in inefficiencies in China last year, is that mostly in Powertrain? Or where did that -- how did that break down?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mostly in Electrical Architecture.
componenttext: Mostly in Electrical Architecture.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Electrical Architecture, okay. And then just quickly on the Singapore deal. I guess, it was just like -- it seems like this draws heavily on maybe the automatic acquisition. I was wondering if there's a little bit of a change in strategy with that asset,
componenttext: Electrical Architecture, okay. And then just quickly on the Singapore deal. I guess, it was just like -- it seems like this draws heavily on maybe the automatic acquisition. I was wondering if there's a little bit of a change in strategy with that asset, where you're going more after the sort of shared mobility concept versus potentially signing that to OEs, or seem to be on the margin, wanting maybe a little bit more of that work in-house. And then how -- for this, a, is that true? And then b, for this deal, how does the OE or other partners sort of get involved in this? I guess, why do they come to you as the first point of entry?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they came to us because we provide the full suite of services, and they were less focused on what type of vehicle we're actually using. So the vehicle there right now is actually -- it's another Audi SQ5. The additional 5 vehicles that we're going t
componenttext: Well, they came to us because we provide the full suite of services, and they were less focused on what type of vehicle we're actually using. So the vehicle there right now is actually -- it's another Audi SQ5. The additional 5 vehicles that we're going to select, it's a choice between 2 OEs. I don't want to get into that, they'll be fully electric. And they're really focused less on the car, but how does the overall system were? Not only the vehicle, but also how does the vehicle interact from an infrastructure standpoint, and how do we put a cloud-based system in that allows the government of Singapore to operate a mobility on-demand service, okay? So it goes above and beyond that, so that they can drop that service in. So I would say that's an expansion of what we've previously contemplated. We think there's a lot they will learn. There's a lot we will learn. I think the mobility on-demand, quite frankly, what you're seeing is a space of the market moving much faster to get automated driving than the traditional OEs. And although all the traditional OEs are focused on it, and as you know, some are further along than others. When you look at the nontraditional players out there in the mobility space, they're moving much more aggressively, much faster, and it seems to be a bigger priority. And we want to be a part of that. We want to be one of the first movers in that.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is it fair to assume that the automatic asset has shifted a little bit towards providing that type of solution versus trying to sort of position that more to OEs for owned autonomy, if you will?
componenttext: So is it fair to assume that the automatic asset has shifted a little bit towards providing that type of solution versus trying to sort of position that more to OEs for owned autonomy, if you will?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, listen, I think -- I don't think the strategy has changed at all. I guess, given the pace of change and the desire to move quickly, that the mobility providers and nontraditional folks out there are looking to ramp it up faster and, therefore, are mor
componenttext: No, listen, I think -- I don't think the strategy has changed at all. I guess, given the pace of change and the desire to move quickly, that the mobility providers and nontraditional folks out there are looking to ramp it up faster and, therefore, are more interested in that part of automatic that we have to offer. The traditional OEs, there are some that we're working with or providing automatic algorithms to. There are others, to your point, that are developing their own.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Lim from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Lim from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. Are you seeing any kind of risk in North American production in the second half? I know that your latest guidance takes all the latest information into consideration, but we're seeing some inventory heaviness in certain s
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. Are you seeing any kind of risk in North American production in the second half? I know that your latest guidance takes all the latest information into consideration, but we're seeing some inventory heaviness in certain segment pockets.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, we're obviously watching it very closely. In other words, obviously, in an announcement last week with Ford and such. At this point, what we see is in the forecast. We haven't had any updates or we have not seen any softening at this point bey
componenttext: Yes, David, we're obviously watching it very closely. In other words, obviously, in an announcement last week with Ford and such. At this point, what we see is in the forecast. We haven't had any updates or we have not seen any softening at this point beyond the volume estimates that we have provided.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then recent news this morning, Samsung and Marelli, discussions there. How would that impact your infotainment business from a competitive standpoint? And then secondly, would you guys consider selling off infotainment if -- obviously, if the
componenttext: Got you. And then recent news this morning, Samsung and Marelli, discussions there. How would that impact your infotainment business from a competitive standpoint? And then secondly, would you guys consider selling off infotainment if -- obviously, if there was the right price for it?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start with the last, and then we can respond  to the first. Listen, our infotainment business, we consider to be very strategic. Joe talked about the growth rates. It's going to grow close to 20% this year, and I think it accelerates in 2017
componenttext: Well, let me start with the last, and then we can respond  to the first. Listen, our infotainment business, we consider to be very strategic. Joe talked about the growth rates. It's going to grow close to 20% this year, and I think it accelerates in 2017 and beyond. So it's a great space, and we think it's a great space where you can see convergence between active safety, infotainment, cluster technology. We're starting to see that today, and we think we got a great position in it. Having said that,  we're about how do we maximize return to shareholders, right? And from that perspective, I guess, I would never say never, but I think it's highly unlikely based on what we view the opportunities to be in that space. With respect to the story today about Samsung and Magneti Marelli, we're very familiar with both companies. And if that were something to happen, it's not something that we're overly concerned about.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Emmanuel Rosner from CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Emmanuel Rosner from CLSA.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first, a quick point of clarification on China and sort of the issues you're seeing with certain automakers in the Powertrain business. When you look sort of like at the full year outlook by now, I think, up until now, you've sort of expected to outp
componenttext: Just first, a quick point of clarification on China and sort of the issues you're seeing with certain automakers in the Powertrain business. When you look sort of like at the full year outlook by now, I think, up until now, you've sort of expected to outperform the market quite a bit. What is sort of your outlook for full year, your own full year China revenue in comparison to the market now?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're, right now, looking at full year China growth of 9%, adjusted growth of 9%. As I mentioned, we have a view of China production growth at about 4% or 5% of the market on the full year. Again, there will be some bouncing around in Q3 and Q4 wi
componenttext: Yes. So we're, right now, looking at full year China growth of 9%, adjusted growth of 9%. As I mentioned, we have a view of China production growth at about 4% or 5% of the market on the full year. Again, there will be some bouncing around in Q3 and Q4 with those rates, obviously, just given what happened last year and just the comparables year-over-year. But for full year, when it settles, 9% growth and about 5% of the market.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, just shifting to the ADAS opportunity. Obviously, significant content opportunity over time. At the same time, a lot of the sort of components seem to be into becoming significantly cheaper very quickly. And then, obviou
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, just shifting to the ADAS opportunity. Obviously, significant content opportunity over time. At the same time, a lot of the sort of components seem to be into becoming significantly cheaper very quickly. And then, obviously, a lot of it has to do with ramping up volume. What is sort of the environment you're seeing in terms of price progression for active safety content and component? And is that still -- in terms of getting that to sort of reasonable margin, is that still consistent with it?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our price outlook hasn't changed. We still think around 2% is the right number for Delphi, overall. We actually -- we're a little lower than that in Q2. You're right, Electronics and Safety tends to be our one segment where our prices are a little bi
componenttext: Yes. Our price outlook hasn't changed. We still think around 2% is the right number for Delphi, overall. We actually -- we're a little lower than that in Q2. You're right, Electronics and Safety tends to be our one segment where our prices are a little bit higher, 2.5% to 3%. But again, we're comfortable with that range, don't see things significantly changing. And as I mentioned, one benefit that we do see the margin over time and expect to continue to see, as these newer product lines grow in volume, material savings also becomes more available to us. So as we buy more, we're able to leverage that spend better. A product line at $100 million, there's only so much leverage you can do. As these get to $0.5 billion and beyond, there's obviously more leverage over the supply base.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Emmanuel, if I can add, I mean, we're now at a point, we've talked previously -- we talked about specifically with the active safety about in investing mode. We're in profit mode now. It's not where E&S margins are, but we're clearly making money. I
componenttext: Yes. Emmanuel, if I can add, I mean, we're now at a point, we've talked previously -- we talked about specifically with the active safety about in investing mode. We're in profit mode now. It's not where E&S margins are, but we're clearly making money. I think with respect to price pressure with -- specifically as it relates to active safety, it really somewhat depends on what sort of active safety solution you're talking about, right? If it's level 1, where it's just a camera or just a radar, right, that, as you know, that -- we're an industry that commoditize itself very, very quickly. And to Joe's point, we're really good at getting cost out when we get volume and leveraging the manufacturing plant as well as getting material savings. As you get into integrated solution, where you're fusing sensors, that's a much different scenario. And there are only a few players that can actually do that, we, being one of them. And I think in those sorts of scenarios -- and that's where the space is headed. In those sort of scenarios, the pricing pressure is actually very reasonable. It's there. I mean, it's always there, but it's much more  reasonable.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton from KeyBanc.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions. One, given the lower organic growth expected here in this year, should we just immediately assume that next year and the following year the organic growth rate is likely to also step down by maybe a comparable amount? Or is that an un
componenttext: Two quick questions. One, given the lower organic growth expected here in this year, should we just immediately assume that next year and the following year the organic growth rate is likely to also step down by maybe a comparable amount? Or is that an unreasonable expectation?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, I mean, we're looking at 2017 now. If we were to start with, overall, with our global vehicle production today, if we're to snap the truck line, including passenger vehicle and commercial vehicle, our outlook is roughly 1% volume growth. With resp
componenttext: Listen, I mean, we're looking at 2017 now. If we were to start with, overall, with our global vehicle production today, if we're to snap the truck line, including passenger vehicle and commercial vehicle, our outlook is roughly 1% volume growth. With respect to growth over market, that's something we're still working through. I would think it's roughly in line with what we're seeing this year or more, depending on what we see in terms of acceleration in active safety, infotainment, power electronics, all the areas that Joe just talked about.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is, you're competing with some very formidable competitors in the, whether it be active safety or connectivity or autonomous driving vehicles and so forth. My question is, does the fact that you have an Electrical Archit
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is, you're competing with some very formidable competitors in the, whether it be active safety or connectivity or autonomous driving vehicles and so forth. My question is, does the fact that you have an Electrical Architecture business give you an advantage? Or is it more along the lines of it's a separate business that just is growing as vehicles are electrifying? I guess, I'm wondering if there's synergies between that and the other portions of your business that maybe gives you a leg up versus, let's say, a Bosch or a Conti, or somebody else along those lines?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I mean, to your point, they're terrific competitors. They have great technology, as do we. But having Electrical Architecture that really enables, right -- it's an enabler of everything that we're talking about, whether it's active safety, au
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I mean, to your point, they're terrific competitors. They have great technology, as do we. But having Electrical Architecture that really enables, right -- it's an enabler of everything that we're talking about, whether it's active safety, automated driving or vehicle electrification, electrification of the Powertrain, and having the ability to combine that know-how with what we know at E&S and Powertrain and areas, for example, like which we're doing for VW. Combining those capabilities is significant. We're looking at similar opportunities from a technology standpoint as it relates to infotainment and clusters. So having that capability and the ability to take out costs and take out complexity based on our experience in that segment is huge.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Kevin mentioned earlier, I think 48-volt's another example of that. If you think of -- we have to partner on the motor, the e-turbo and the battery, but the rest of the content of that 48-volt vehicle is Delphi content. And without the Elect
componenttext: Yes. I think, Kevin mentioned earlier, I think 48-volt's another example of that. If you think of -- we have to partner on the motor, the e-turbo and the battery, but the rest of the content of that 48-volt vehicle is Delphi content. And without the Electrical Architecture business, it would obviously not be possible to put that system together at that level. So that's -- vehicle electrification will clearly be one where both the Powertrain business and the E/EA are able to collaborate benefits.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from the line of Chris McNally from Evercore.
componenttext: And our final question comes from the line of Chris McNally from Evercore.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Just a follow-up on the customer drags within Powertrain, similar to some of the questions at the beginning of the call. Is there a way to think about this as a customer-specific diesel production issue? Or is it really several customers and a representation of a broader lower diesel sales?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's more than one customer. It's, call it, 4 customers. I do think there is some consistency in what we're seeing across those customers. They are -- and we've talked to each of them, and we're obviously engaged. The message back from them has the consis
componenttext: It's more than one customer. It's, call it, 4 customers. I do think there is some consistency in what we're seeing across those customers. They are -- and we've talked to each of them, and we're obviously engaged. The message back from them has the consistency of exactly what I have said, which is managing diesel inventories, heading into summer shutdowns for the back half of the year. And we're dealing with primarily European production, although there is some export to Asia Pac/India that we're seeing impacted as well. So again, hard to draw any broader conclusion than that. We are certainly not at this point where we've had very specific dialogues with the customers. But it is more than one. It isn't just one customer.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if I could augment Joe's comment. Listen, the commercial vehicle side is a strict market. It ended up being a very challenging market for anyone in that space. I think as you look at Powertrain and you look at light-duty diesel, the reality is every
componenttext: Yes, if I could augment Joe's comment. Listen, the commercial vehicle side is a strict market. It ended up being a very challenging market for anyone in that space. I think as you look at Powertrain and you look at light-duty diesel, the reality is every OE has multiple Powertrain platforms, and there is some mix effect. So to Joe's points, listen, we're seeing some dots, and we're trying to connect the dots. They all may not be perfectly correlated because each OE has different inventory levels, quite frankly, has different mix of vehicles and those all come into play. So at times, at a given point in time, it can be some challenging calculus to give you a real specific answer.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But so we should -- when we start to sort of isolate the risk, we should sort of think about it as a diesel-specific issue related to some version of inventory sales rather than a broader Powertrain backlog, which, I think, has been fairly so invest
componenttext: Okay. But so we should -- when we start to sort of isolate the risk, we should sort of think about it as a diesel-specific issue related to some version of inventory sales rather than a broader Powertrain backlog, which, I think, has been fairly so investors' concerns, given Powertrain across multiple suppliers been really where we've been having weakness?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say a light-duty diesel specific issue related to mix near term, I wouldn't draw any conclusion about light-duty diesel penetration from where we sit now that is any different than what we've communicated previously. Is that clear?
componenttext: Yes, so I would say a light-duty diesel specific issue related to mix near term, I wouldn't draw any conclusion about light-duty diesel penetration from where we sit now that is any different than what we've communicated previously. Is that clear?
