componenttext: Just first, a quick point of clarification on China and sort of the issues you're seeing with certain automakers in the Powertrain business. When you look sort of like at the full year outlook by now, I think, up until now, you've sort of expected to outperform the market quite a bit. What is sort of your outlook for full year -- your own full year China revenue in comparison to the market now?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're, right now, looking at full year China growth of 9% -- adjusted growth of 9%. As I mentioned, we have a view of China production growth at about 4% or 5% over market on the full year. Again, there will be some bouncing around in Q3 and Q4 wi
componenttext: Yes. So we're, right now, looking at full year China growth of 9% -- adjusted growth of 9%. As I mentioned, we have a view of China production growth at about 4% or 5% over market on the full year. Again, there will be some bouncing around in Q3 and Q4 with those rates, obviously, just given what happened last year and just the comparables year-over-year. But for full year, when it settles, 9% growth and about 5% over market.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, just shifting to the ADAS opportunity. Obviously, significant content opportunity over time. At the same time, a lot of these sort of components seem to be becoming significantly cheaper very quickly. And obviously, a lo
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, just shifting to the ADAS opportunity. Obviously, significant content opportunity over time. At the same time, a lot of these sort of components seem to be becoming significantly cheaper very quickly. And obviously, a lot of it has to do with ramping up volume. What is sort of the environment you're seeing in terms of price progression for active safety content and component? And is that still -- in terms of getting that to sort of reasonable margin, is that still consistent with it?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our price outlook hasn't changed. We still think around 2% is the right number for Delphi, overall. We actually -- we're a little lower than that in Q2. You're right, Electronics and Safety tends to be our one segment where price is a little bit high
componenttext: Yes. Our price outlook hasn't changed. We still think around 2% is the right number for Delphi, overall. We actually -- we're a little lower than that in Q2. You're right, Electronics and Safety tends to be our one segment where price is a little bit higher, 2.5% to 3%. But again, we're comfortable with that range, don't see things significantly changing. And as I mentioned, one benefit that we do see to margin over time, and expect to continue to see, as these newer product lines grow in volume, material savings also becomes more available to us. So as we buy more, we're able to leverage that spend better. A product line at $100 million, there's only so much leverage you can do. As these get to $0.5 billion and beyond, there's obviously more leverage over a supply base.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Emmanuel, if I can add, I mean, we're now at a point, we've talked previously -- we talked about, specifically, to active safety about in investing mode. We're in profit mode now. It's not where E&S margins are, but we're clearly making money. I thin
componenttext: Yes. Emmanuel, if I can add, I mean, we're now at a point, we've talked previously -- we talked about, specifically, to active safety about in investing mode. We're in profit mode now. It's not where E&S margins are, but we're clearly making money. I think with respect to price pressure with -- specifically as it relates to active safety, it really somewhat depends on what sort of active safety solution you're talking about, right? If it's level 1, where it's just a camera or just a radar, right, that, as you know, that -- we're in an industry that commoditizes itself very, very quickly. And to Joe's point, we're really good at getting cost out when we get volume and leveraging the manufacturing plant as well as getting material savings. As you get into integrated solution, where you're fusing sensors, that's a much different scenario. And there are only a few players that can actually do that, we, being one of them. And I think in those sorts of scenarios -- and that's where this space is headed. In those sort of scenarios, the pricing pressure is actually very reasonable. It's there. I mean, it's always there, but it's much more reasonable.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Listen, I mean, we're looking at 2017 now. If we were to start with, overall, with our global vehicle production today, if we were to snap the chalk line, including passenger vehicle and commercial vehicle, our outlook is roughly 1% volume growth. With respect to growth over market, that's something we're still working through. I would think it's roughly in line with what we're seeing this year or more, depending on what we see in terms of acceleration in active safety, infotainment, power electronics, all the areas that Joe just talked about.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is, you're competing against some very formidable competitors in the, whether it be active safety or connectivity or autonomous driving vehicles and so forth. My question is, does the fact that you have an Electrical Arc
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is, you're competing against some very formidable competitors in the, whether it be active safety or connectivity or autonomous driving vehicles and so forth. My question is, does the fact that you have an Electrical Architecture business give you an advantage? Or is it more along the lines of it's a separate business that just is growing as vehicles are electrifying? I guess, I'm wondering if there's synergies between that and the other portions of your business that maybe gives you a leg up versus, let's say, a Bosch or a Conti, or somebody else along those lines?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I mean, to your point, they're terrific competitors. They have great technology, as do we. But having Electrical Architecture that really enables, right -- it's an enabler of everything that we're talking about, whether it's active safety, au
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I mean, to your point, they're terrific competitors. They have great technology, as do we. But having Electrical Architecture that really enables, right -- it's an enabler of everything that we're talking about, whether it's active safety, automated driving or vehicle electrification, electrification of the Powertrain, and having the ability to combine that know-how with what we know at E&S and Powertrain in areas, for example, like Z-Fast which we're doing for VW. Combining those capabilities is significant. We're looking at similar opportunities from a technology standpoint as it relates to infotainment and clusters. So having that capability and the ability to take out cost and take out complexity based on our experience in that segment is huge.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Kevin mentioned earlier, I think 48-volt's another example of that. If you think of -- we have to partner on the motor, the e-turbo and the battery, but the rest of the content in that 48-volt vehicle is Delphi content. And without the Elect
componenttext: Yes. I think, Kevin mentioned earlier, I think 48-volt's another example of that. If you think of -- we have to partner on the motor, the e-turbo and the battery, but the rest of the content in that 48-volt vehicle is Delphi content. And without the Electrical Architecture business, it would obviously not be possible to put that system together at that level. So that's -- vehicle electrification is clearly going to be one where both the Powertrain business and E/EA are able to collaborate and benefit.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the customer drags within Powertrain, similar to some of the questions at the beginning of the call. Is there a way to think about this as a customer-specific diesel production issue? Or is it really several customers and a representat
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the customer drags within Powertrain, similar to some of the questions at the beginning of the call. Is there a way to think about this as a customer-specific diesel production issue? Or is it really several customers and a representation of a broader lower diesel sales?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's more than one customer. It's, call it, 4 customers. I do think there is some consistency in what we're seeing across those customers. They are -- and we've talked to each of them, and we're obviously engaged. The message back from them has the consis
componenttext: It's more than one customer. It's, call it, 4 customers. I do think there is some consistency in what we're seeing across those customers. They are -- and we've talked to each of them, and we're obviously engaged. The message back from them has the consistency of exactly what I have said, which is managing diesel inventories, heading into summer shutdowns for the back half of the year. And we're dealing with primarily European production, although there is some export to Asia Pac/India that we're seeing impacted as well. So again, hard to draw any broader conclusions than that. We are certainly not, at this point, where we've had very specific dialogues with the customers. But it is more than one. It isn't just one customer.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if I could augment Joe's comment. Listen, on the commercial vehicle side it's trade [ph] market. It ended up being a very challenging market for anyone in that space. I think as you look at Powertrain and you look at light-duty diesel, the reality is
componenttext: Yes, if I could augment Joe's comment. Listen, on the commercial vehicle side it's trade [ph] market. It ended up being a very challenging market for anyone in that space. I think as you look at Powertrain and you look at light-duty diesel, the reality is every OE has multiple Powertrain platforms, and there is some mix effect. So to Joe's point, listen, we're seeing some dots, and we're trying to connect the dots. They all may not be perfectly correlated because each OE has different inventory levels, quite frankly, has different mix of vehicles and those all come into play. So at times -- at a given point in time, it can be some challenging calculus to give you a real specific answer.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But so we should -- when we start to sort of isolate the risk, we should sort of think about it as a diesel-specific issue related to some version of inventory sales rather than a broader Powertrain backlog, which, I think, has been, fairly so, inve
componenttext: Okay. But so we should -- when we start to sort of isolate the risk, we should sort of think about it as a diesel-specific issue related to some version of inventory sales rather than a broader Powertrain backlog, which, I think, has been, fairly so, investors' concerns, given Powertrain across multiple suppliers been really where we've been having weakness?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes, so I would say a light-duty diesel specific issue related to mix near term, I wouldn't draw any conclusion about light-duty diesel penetration from where we sit now that is any different than what we've communicated previously. Is that clear?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kayla, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Delphi Q3 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Elena Rosman, D
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Kayla, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Delphi Q3 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Elena Rosman, Delphi's Vice President of Investor Relations. Elena, you may begin.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kayla, and good morning. Thank you for joining Delphi's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. To follow along with today's presentation, our slides can be found at delphi.com under the Investors section of the website. And consistent w
componenttext:
Thank you, Kayla, and good morning. Thank you for joining Delphi's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. To follow along with today's presentation, our slides can be found at delphi.com under the Investors section of the website. 
And consistent with prior calls, today's review of our actual and forecasted financials excludes restructuring and other special items and will address the continuing operations of Delphi. The reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures is included at the back of the presentation and the press release. Now we ask that you look at Slide 2 for a disclosure on our forward-looking statements, which reflects Delphi's current view of future financial performance, which may materially differ from our actual performance. 
Joining us today will be Kevin Clark, Delphi's President and CEO; and Joe Massaro, CFO and Senior Vice President. As seen on Slide 3, Kevin will cover company highlights for the quarter, and then Joe will get into the financial results and the outlook for the remainder of the year in more detail. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Kevin Clark.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Elena. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Before Joe gets into our financial results, let me provide some context on the third quarter.Beginning with the highlights on Slide 5. We had a solid quarter delivering strong revenue and ear
componenttext:
Thanks, Elena. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. Before Joe gets into our financial results, let me provide some context on the third quarter.
Beginning with the highlights on Slide 5. We had a solid quarter delivering strong revenue and earnings growth. Revenue increased 10%, driven by double-digit growth in both our Electronics and Safety and Electrical Architecture segments and mid-single-digit growth in our Powertrain business. 
Operating income increased to $531 million and operating margins expanded to 13%, driven by flow-through on volume growth and continued cost structure optimization, partially offset by some strategic investments. Earnings per share increased 17% to $1.50. And we generated strong cash flow, a portion of which we used to return $175 million of cash to shareholders, bringing the year-to-date total for share repurchases and dividends to roughly $770 million.
As Joe will cover later, we also took actions during the quarter to strengthen our capital structure and divest our mechatronics business, continuing the rotation of our product portfolio into high-growth sectors. Lastly, we delivered another strong bookings quarter, bringing our year-to-date total to $18 billion. The leadership team are being focused on executing flawlessly and delivering on our commitments. 
Turning to Slide 6. The automotive industry's transformation has been the theme at each of this year's major auto shows with the highlights being the megatrends of safe, green and connected, which are at the heart of our strategy. The theme of the recent Commercial Vehicles Show in Hanover was around new mobility. I met with a number of customers who are looking to Delphi to help solve some of their toughest challenges resulting from these megatrends. In addition to the usual discussions regarding new powertrain technologies and their impact on increased fuel efficiency and reduced CO2 emissions, much of the dialogue was around vehicle connectivity, active safety, automated driving as a means of increasing driver productivity, enhancing vehicle safety and improving fuel economy, each of which translates into real cost savings for fleet managers.
And turning to Slide 7. At the Paris Auto Show, vehicle electrification was front and center as customers looked to close regulatory gaps on CO2 emissions and improve fuel economy. Industry experts and even some of our customers are now forecasting 25% to 30% of vehicles to be electrified by 2025. And given our strength in powertrain technology, electrical architecture and power electronics, Delphi has unique competitive solutions in the intelligent electrification of passenger vehicles that cost-effectively help our customers meet increasingly stringent regulatory standards. 
These solutions are shown in greater detail on Slide 8. We're well positioned regardless of the trend in vehicle electrification. And our content per vehicle grows with increased electrification. From 2 to 4x the content of a gas internal combustion engine on a 48-volt vehicle, depending on whether we're doing components or a full system integration, all the way up to 7 to 8x the content on a full electric car. So the trend towards increased electrification is very good for Delphi.
Slide 9 highlights our $18 billion of bookings year-to-date, which includes large complex wins for Electrical Architecture in Asia and additional content wins in North America; awards for gas fuel injection systems with OEMs in both North America and Europe; and major infotainment wins, including a program for a large European OEM; and an active safety win with Changan in China. On the right side of the chart are the cumulative bookings for some of our faster-growing technologies underpinning the safe, green and connected megatrends. 
Let's turn to Slide 10 for another example. The road to increased vehicle connectivity and automation requires faster speeds for data processing and more high-speed computing power. High-speed vehicle computers, such as the multi-domain controller we launch with Audi in 2017 and the integrated cockpit controller we launch with Volvo in 2018, make decisions 34,000x faster than humans. Through the fusion of sensors and the integration of advanced software algorithms, these technologies reduce architectural complexity while increasing computer processing power and enabling vehicle connectivity.
This serves as a nice bridge to Slide 11, which provides an overview of our recently announced partnership with Mobileye. We've experienced significant interest from customers in the U.S., Europe, Korea, China and Japan for a Central Sensing Localization and Planning automated driving platform. When you combine Mobileye's vision in road experience management systems with Delphi's sensor suite, automated driving software from Ottomatika and our multi-domain controller, no other entity comes close to matching the quality or the capability of this automated driving system. Our collaboration is off to a fast start and is making significant headway. In fact, you're going to be able to see and ride in the first demonstration vehicles, along with several other important technologies, at the Consumer Electronics Show in January. 
Finally, on Slide 12, I'm proud to say Delphi's received 2 nominations for the Automotive News PACE Awards, one of the industry recognition forms for innovation. Delphi's being recognized for its gesture recognition technology, which recently launched on the all-new BMW 7 Series, and for 360-degree short-range radar for ADAS systems that provides superior radar performance while enabling many new sensing capabilities that recently launched on a new Hyundai vehicle with several other OEs launching next year. This is really a great testament to the capabilities and dedication of our teams, which have received over 60 nominations and won 18 PACE Awards over the past 2 decades. 
So with that, I'm going to hand the call over to Joe.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. I will review our third quarter financial performance before discussing our guidance for the remainder of the year. Beginning on Slide 14 with a summary of our third quarter financial performance. We are very p
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. I will review our third quarter financial performance before discussing our guidance for the remainder of the year. 
Beginning on Slide 14 with a summary of our third quarter financial performance. We are very pleased with the third quarter results, as Kevin mentioned. Adjusted revenue grew double digits, up 10%. Our EBITDA margins expanded 60 basis points to 17.2%. And operating margins expanded 10 basis points to 13%. Earnings per share grew 17%, driven by solid share -- by solid sales growth. And in the quarter, we generated operating cash flow of $415 million and purchased 1.5 million shares, totaling approximately $100 million. With our 7874 issue behind us, our low tax rate, 17% for the quarter, continues to allow us to deploy capital more effectively.
Slide 15 provides greater detail on revenue in the quarter. Sales growth outpaced expectations with strong performance around the world, particularly in Europe and China. Beginning with the walk in the left, sales volume more than offset price, foreign exchange and commodity headwinds. FX headwinds were largely driven by the weakening British pound and Chinese RMB, as we had previously guided. And the HellermannTyton acquisition contributed approximately $200 million of revenue, up 10% year-over-year, partially offset by the Reception Systems divestiture. Moving to the right, with the exception of South America, all regions benefited from strong growth. Again, in particular, China was up 27% for the quarter, benefiting in part from a weak Q3 2015 while Europe benefited from strong growth in Electrical Architecture and E&S, driven by robust new program launches. 
Turning to operating income. Slide 16 walks the year-over-year change for the third quarter. Overall, operating margins were in line at 13%. Strong sales growth, combined with accretive M&A and net performance, contributed to margin expansion in the quarter, partially offset by price and FX headwinds. Net performance was favorable despite higher levels of engineering spend, primarily related to our automated driving initiatives in E&S and the operational inefficiencies in Electrical Architecture we highlighted last quarter.
On Slide 17, you can see a breakdown of performance by segment. Electrical Architecture had adjusted growth of 11% with new launches benefiting Europe and higher volumes in China. Margins expanded 30 basis points year-over-year on higher volumes. As previously discussed, we continue to experience operational inefficiencies in the business, which negatively impacted our performance in the quarter by approximately $15 million, in line with our previous expectations.
Powertrain also delivered above-market adjusted growth of 4% with strong double-digit gains in Gas Direct Injection and variable valve train, more than offsetting mid- to high single-digit declines in commercial and light-duty diesel volumes. Powertrain margins expanded 30 basis points on strong manufacturing performance, partially offset by the FX impact from the weakening GBP and Chinese RMB, primarily related to the FX transaction impact in our Powertrain U.K. and China operations.
Electronics and Safety adjusted growth accelerated to a record 17% in the quarter. New program launches, particularly in active safety and infotainment, continued to drive double-digit growth. As Kevin mentioned, we are investing alongside this growth to position the company for the acceleration in automated driving opportunities with higher engineering investments in the quarter negatively impacting E&S margins by approximately 40 basis points. 
It is important to note that the segment numbers for both 2015 and 2016 reflect the realignment of our power electronics business from E&S to Powertrain. This move better aligns our propulsion technologies with the changing needs of our customers. The impact is relatively small with break-even sales of approximately $30 million in the quarter.
Turning to Slide 18. EPS grew 17% versus the prior year, representing our third quarter of double-digit EPS growth this year. We exceeded the midpoint of our guidance range by $0.09, driven primarily by the flow-through of higher-than-expected sales. And below-the-line items contributed approximately $0.03, including the results from our nonconsolidated joint ventures.
Turning to Slide 19. The third quarter also proved to be active on the capital structure front. We completed the refinancing of our 2023 senior notes that resulted in a less expensive, longer-tenor capital structure. As you can see, by using new long-term debt denominated in both U.S. dollars and euros, including $300 million of 30-year senior notes at 4.4%, we were able to extend the time to maturity by almost 3 years and optimize the cost of funds, decreasing our interest expense by approximately $20 million annually. And we are generating more free cash flow, driven by higher operating earnings and lower cash taxes, providing more cash for key investments and capital redeployment. 
Our capital allocation strategy remains unchanged. As Kevin mentioned, we signed a definitive agreement to divest our mechatronics business. With annual sales of approximately $250 million, we expect the transaction to close in the fourth quarter. We continue to be very active in the market for acquisitions and investments, focused on companies with leading technologies, strong management teams and operating capabilities that give us the confidence on our ability to integrate and drive synergies. We are committed to paying a competitive dividend and returning excess capital to shareholders. As you can see from our recent track record, since 2014, we've returned over $3.5 billion in the form of share repurchases and dividends. And for the full year, we are on pace to complete $600 million of buybacks, consistent with our prior outlook.
Turning to Slide 20 and starting with the outlook for the fourth quarter on the left. Revenue is expected to be $4.1 billion at the midpoint, reflecting approximately 4% adjusted growth on flat vehicle production, lapping a tough comparable from Q4 2015. Margins, however, are expected to expand 60 basis points year-over-year with strong net performance helped in part by the lapping of the inefficiencies we experienced last year in China. Earnings are expected to be in the range of $1.55 to $1.65, reflecting year-over-year growth of 15% at the midpoint. 
Moving to the right of the slide. You can see our updated full year outlook. We are reflecting the strength of the third quarter performance in our updated full year guidance for sales and earnings. We now expect sales of approximately $16.45 billion at the midpoint, up approximately 7%, and EPS in the range of $6 to $6.10 per share, up 16% over last year.
Now before I hand it back to Kevin for some closing remarks, given the time of the year, we begin to get questions on next year. And I thought it would be helpful to spend a minute on our initial considerations for 2017. As we sit here today, we believe global vehicle production for next year will be flat to 2016 levels. However, with our strong portfolio of relevant technologies, we would expect Delphi to grow mid-single-digit organic, driven by our faster-growing product lines, active safety, infotainment, GDi and vehicle electrification, all of which are expected to grow strong double digits again in 2017.
As always, our team remains focused on optimizing our cost structure and driving increased efficiencies throughout the organization. This relentless focus will allow us to continue to expand operating margins and invest in key technologies, including our CSLP automated driving partnership with Mobileye. Although we experienced significant FX and commodity headwinds in 2016, if spot rates held where they are today, we would only expect $150 million headwind to revenue in 2017.
Lastly, as we noted, the divestiture of mechatronics is expected to close late in the fourth quarter and will be accretive to our 2017 adjusted growth rate, although the sale will be a headwind to reported revenue and operating income. So as we reflect on the future, we have a more competitive technology portfolio, a more flexible business model and a less expensive capital structure that will drive revenue, earnings and cash flow growth through the cycle. 
And with that, I'll now turn it over to Kevin for some closing remarks before we open it up to questions.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Thanks, Joe. Thanks a lot. Now wrapping up our formal comments on Slide 21. As we said, we delivered a strong performance in the third quarter with double-digit sales and earnings growth. We remain confident in our 2016 outlook, which includes 7%
componenttext:
Thanks. Thanks, Joe. Thanks a lot. Now wrapping up our formal comments on Slide 21. As we said, we delivered a strong performance in the third quarter with double-digit sales and earnings growth. We remain confident in our 2016 outlook, which includes 7% organic growth, mid-teens EPS growth and $1.1 billion of free cash flow. And as Joe just mentioned, we continue to aggressively optimize our cost structure to increase our flexibility, continue to expand margins and fund smart investments in technologies that will enhance our competitive position and drive further profitable growth. And we remain focused on executing over the balance of this year and throughout 2017. We're confident that our industry-leading cost structure, operating discipline and safe, green and connected technology portfolio will continue to yield margin expansion and earnings growth. And our ability to convert more income to cash and effectively deploy capital provides additional leverage to drive shareholder value in the years to come. 
So with that, we'll now open up the line for questions.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

And are you thinking about any other changes to the portfolio? And I'm thinking specifically vis-à-vis Powertrain and just given what we're seeing with diesel declines and growth in electrification, how are you thinking about the positioning of that division?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, why don't I -- Rod, if I could start with a little bit of background as it relates to the divestiture. As those of you on the phone, most of you know, we've been talking about our mechatronics business as non-core and slow growth and quite frankly a
componenttext: Okay, why don't I -- Rod, if I could start with a little bit of background as it relates to the divestiture. As those of you on the phone, most of you know, we've been talking about our mechatronics business as non-core and slow growth and quite frankly a headwind to growth over the last couple of years. And as we work to reposition the portfolio and reposition E&S specifically as less mechanical, a little less electrical and much more software orientation, this was a logical step in continuing to rotate that overall portfolio. And in terms of what we do with the business, we've been actually working on that for, let's call it, the last year or so. I'll let Joe touch on the numbers.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rod, we're going to -- we won't be disclosing proceeds and deal specifics until the transaction closes. We expect it to close in December of this coming year. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks, think of revenue as approximately $250 million. I wo
componenttext: Yes, Rod, we're going to -- we won't be disclosing proceeds and deal specifics until the transaction closes. We expect it to close in December of this coming year. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks, think of revenue as approximately $250 million. I would think of EBIT around the $70 million number. And remember, when we had a similar situation with Reception Systems, those businesses are more profitable relative in the portfolio because we no longer -- last couple of years, we haven't been investing in engineering and pursuit.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any thoughts on the Powertrain and some of the trends that you're observing there on diesel?
componenttext: And any thoughts on the Powertrain and some of the trends that you're observing there on diesel?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, why don't I start? And again, Joe, you can make any comments. Listen, Powertrain is an important part of our overall portfolio. Clearly, there is a headwind as it relates to light-duty diesel penetration in the market. Now offsetting that is signific
componenttext: Yes, why don't I start? And again, Joe, you can make any comments. Listen, Powertrain is an important part of our overall portfolio. Clearly, there is a headwind as it relates to light-duty diesel penetration in the market. Now offsetting that is significant growth in Gas Direct Injection and variable valve train technologies. So to put it in perspective, GDi for us this year will grow close to 50%, variable valve train close to 40%. So we're working very hard to close the gap in terms of revenue headwind on light-duty diesel with replacement technologies on the gas side of the engine. And in addition to that, the rationale for our movement of the power electronics out of E&S into Powertrain is, given the trend in light-duty diesel, we're seeing more of that customer interaction quite frankly take place within the powertrain functions of our customers than where it's been historically as they work to improve fuel economy and reduce CO2 emissions. So that was the rationale for why we've moved that product line there. And that's another product line where we're seeing, I think, close to 100% growth this year in revenue, albeit off of a very small number today.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rod, it's Joe. Just one last thing I meant to finish on mechatronics, I would also note that we -- as we look for that, that business is Western European-based. So in addition to the sales proceeds, we're facing a fairly significant shutdown cost, call it
componenttext: Rod, it's Joe. Just one last thing I meant to finish on mechatronics, I would also note that we -- as we look for that, that business is Western European-based. So in addition to the sales proceeds, we're facing a fairly significant shutdown cost, call it, late '18 and '19 as we deemphasize growth in that business. So we'll also be out from under that as well as we move forward with the sale.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's not surprising. I think you guys have talked about this. One other thing I wanted to ask, and I'll let other people ask questions, but could you just talk about broadly the outlook for R&D spending as we think about 2017 and beyond? I know you w
componenttext: Yes, it's not surprising. I think you guys have talked about this. One other thing I wanted to ask, and I'll let other people ask questions, but could you just talk about broadly the outlook for R&D spending as we think about 2017 and beyond? I know you were targeting 18%, 19% EBITDA as in mid-14s EBIT towards the end of the decade, like 50 basis points of expansion per year. Some of your peers are pointing to increasing pressures from R&D. And you guys have highlighted quite a bit of spending on active safety and autonomous driving. So can you size up what kind of headwind you're looking at and how we should be putting that into context for margins?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Rod, the way -- and I mentioned the 2017, some of the initial planning considerations, we're -- and it's still early days from a planning perspective and we're going through investments now. Clearly, we'll spend more on automated driving. We
componenttext: Yes, I think, Rod, the way -- and I mentioned the 2017, some of the initial planning considerations, we're -- and it's still early days from a planning perspective and we're going through investments now. Clearly, we'll spend more on automated driving. We'll increase that. As we're setting our targets internally, we're focused on, call it, 30 to 40 basis points of margin expansion next year. And that would be inclusive of the -- any investment on automated driving.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could just kind of follow up on sort of that margin direction you were just going in, quite simplistically if you can, what kind of sales growth do you need to maintain margins? And what kind of sales growth do you need to expand margins? And I
componenttext: Maybe if I could just kind of follow up on sort of that margin direction you were just going in, quite simplistically if you can, what kind of sales growth do you need to maintain margins? And what kind of sales growth do you need to expand margins? And I'm kind of trying to think about all else equal here because, I mean, there could be some big swings in global volume. And I'm just trying to understand. I mean, I think we tend to oversimplify and think about incremental and decrementals but just curious what you're thinking about what kind of sales growth you need to maintain margins.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, listen, John, let me take a first shot at it. Listen, our business model really remains unchanged, right? We built a plan and worked to execute where we have performance initiatives that offset price and economics. And I think what we talked about in
componenttext: Yes, listen, John, let me take a first shot at it. Listen, our business model really remains unchanged, right? We built a plan and worked to execute where we have performance initiatives that offset price and economics. And I think what we talked about in the past is the 10% reduction in vehicle production would translate into about 150 basis points of margin degradation and on the upside, flow-through of each dollar of volume flow-through kind of $0.18 to $0.20 of operating income. That model really doesn't change, and I think we've exhibited times in the past where whether it was in a specific region or it's in a particular quarter where we have the ability to flex our cost structure. It's one of the benefits of 90% of our hourly workers being low-cost countries, 75% of our manufacturing facilities in low-cost countries and high-level temp labor where we have the ability to flex. And so at the end of the day, I'm not sure I have a specific number, Joe. I'll defer to you.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. At this point in the planning process, John, I'd sort of revert back to what I just mentioned. In a flat market with appropriate levels of investment to support automated driving, we are targeting the 30 to 40 basis points of expansion. I would calib
componenttext: Yes. At this point in the planning process, John, I'd sort of revert back to what I just mentioned. In a flat market with appropriate levels of investment to support automated driving, we are targeting the 30 to 40 basis points of expansion. I would calibrate off of that.

componenttext: Yes. So with respect to the threshold for profitability, again, nothing's changed there. They're at or above our current profit margin. componenttext: I have a question around diesel mix, just following up on that, and then I'll ask one on active safety. You talked just 500 diesel, 250 gas per engine content. Or do you still have a base customers with you're doing the diesel but the gas engines are naturally aspirated so there's more of a risk there?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is more around active safety. And since we last chatted on calls, [indiscernible] has come up with some "guidelines" for testing active safety systems and voluntary compliance. We've seen actually a startup according to Tech Crunch w
componenttext: Okay. Second question is more around active safety. And since we last chatted on calls, [indiscernible] has come up with some "guidelines" for testing active safety systems and voluntary compliance. We've seen actually a startup according to Tech Crunch with ADAS aftermarket product due to [indiscernible]. Can you just maybe comment on how you see that evolving? And then to what extent is that you're having these discussions and in your partnership with Mobileye sort of the idea of regulatory compliance we can walk you through almost FAA, FDA style that compliance process? And to what extent is that a competitive advantage in E&S?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I think, we, Delphi, whether it's within E&S or other businesses have, for a long time, customers in a regulatory authority as it relates to shaping regulation. Regulation within automated driving and active safety is good, right? It forces s
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I think, we, Delphi, whether it's within E&S or other businesses have, for a long time, customers in a regulatory authority as it relates to shaping regulation. Regulation within automated driving and active safety is good, right? It forces standardization. And once you have standardization, suppliers and automotive OEs can work on technology as well as commercializing the costs and coming down the curve, which allows faster, more rapid adoption. So that's something that is very positive. As we talk about our project with Mobileye. One of the big, compelling reasons they are to do that was how do we develop quickly a standardized system that can be leveraged across OEs or across vehicle platforms, can be done quickly and can be done in a very competitive cost because, as you know, our OEs are very, very focused on costs as it relates to technology.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Jonas for Morgan Stanley.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions. The first is on active safety. And as these systems kind of -- I mean, you can't watch any sporting event or, frankly, any, let's say, 10-minute stretch of television without seeing another advertisement of a car stopping before hurting
componenttext: Just 2 questions. The first is on active safety. And as these systems kind of -- I mean, you can't watch any sporting event or, frankly, any, let's say, 10-minute stretch of television without seeing another advertisement of a car stopping before hurting somebody or killing somebody. And -- but I mean, it seems to me that you should be -- you're in a great position to start getting some of the real-world data at a kind of geometric rate to analyze how much safer these technologies are, given the level of costs in your systems that you're providing your OEM customers. So I guess, the high-level question is, putting the fully autonomous cars that could be, and theoretically, thousands of times safer than human driving aside just for a moment, how much per unit, roughly, do you think the content is, per unit, to kind of have a dramatic, like a 30% or 40% or 40% or 50% reduction of vehicle-to-vehicle or vehicle-to-pedestrian type collisions based on the data and the technology and U.S. member of the scientific community you're observing? Is it hundreds of dollars? Is it $1,000? Or is it thousands of dollars? I gave you those.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Adam, it's a very accurate observation, and it's a great question. Listen, we've been really clear as it relates to -- we look at automated driving as on the spectrum of active safety. And the reality is if you get to level 3 automated driving, you g
componenttext: Yes, Adam, it's a very accurate observation, and it's a great question. Listen, we've been really clear as it relates to -- we look at automated driving as on the spectrum of active safety. And the reality is if you get to level 3 automated driving, you get 80% of safety benefit and 20% of the costs, right? So -- and we estimate total onboarding for automated driving at -- Joe, help me. .

componenttext: For automated driving, it's a couple of thousand dollars.

componenttext: At full volume.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, a couple of thousand dollars. So listen, a lot of the benefit can be really, really drive there. As you look at going from level 3 to level 4 or level 5, level 5 especially, we see the demand being primarily driven by the mobility providers, the f fo
componenttext: Yes, a couple of thousand dollars. So listen, a lot of the benefit can be really, really drive there. As you look at going from level 3 to level 4 or level 5, level 5 especially, we see the demand being primarily driven by the mobility providers, the f folks that you're familiar with, who have another economic incentive to have a driver out of a car and to be fully autonomous. Now there are additional OEs we are working on fully automated vehicles as well. And I think that's a great question, and our view is level 3, you get 80% of the benefit, 20% of the cost.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's very helpful, and I think that, that answer is consistent with some of your Tier 1 competitors. But I must say, I've been asking every OEM this same question, we don't get the same specific answer. We get either no answer or maybe thousands o
componenttext: Well, that's very helpful, and I think that, that answer is consistent with some of your Tier 1 competitors. But I must say, I've been asking every OEM this same question, we don't get the same specific answer. We get either no answer or maybe thousands of dollars. And I'm just curious, is that because maybe if you can really get 80% of the benefit from maybe only $5 or $10 a month of monthly payment on a 72-month car loan, boy, people might want to wait. You could have a buyers' strike, right? I mean, I don't know if you have any views on that, like, whether we could have an accelerated replacement demand based on safety and at the margin uninsurable cars, which could create some dislocation on the market. I don't know if it kind of comment on that. Maybe it's another topic, but I just had one other follow-up question.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I'm not sure I fully understand the last part of your question. I would just say, at the end of the day, we've been booking north of $1 billion of active safety programs per year over the last 4 years, and we'll do that this year as well. In o
componenttext: Sure. Well, I'm not sure I fully understand the last part of your question. I would just say, at the end of the day, we've been booking north of $1 billion of active safety programs per year over the last 4 years, and we'll do that this year as well. In our active safety business, we'll grow close to 40% this year, and revenues in active safety will be north of 40% next year. So we see a tremendous ramp-up in active safety sales. It's something that our customers are asking for. It's something that consumers are pulling [ph]. It's helping OEs sell cars. And I think that's really important.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. All right. Just one final question. You mentioned the outlook for 2017 as flat global light vehicle production. That is a big -- well, you may be able to handle that kind of environment while growing margins 30 or 40 basis points, and you can handl
componenttext: Great. All right. Just one final question. You mentioned the outlook for 2017 as flat global light vehicle production. That is a big -- well, you may be able to handle that kind of environment while growing margins 30 or 40 basis points, and you can handle only 150 bps of margin absorption with a 10% decline. Your customers, your OEMs are, let's say, unfortunately, not in as good a position. They tend to see margins drop pretty significantly when we go flat. So I guess, with that, if that's historic, what we've seen this time and time again, if that trend holds, what are your expectations for increased pricing pressure? I know it's always hard, and we know the communication on that, but could you not bake in a bit more aggressive price-downs than we've seen over the last cyclical period of low to mid-double-digit global production growth into next year?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, I'll augment my response. I think one thing as you look at let me go production where we sit today versus where we sit historically, I think there are 2 factors that you need to consider. And I can't quantify it for you, but I think they're q
componenttext: Yes. Listen, I'll augment my response. I think one thing as you look at let me go production where we sit today versus where we sit historically, I think there are 2 factors that you need to consider. And I can't quantify it for you, but I think they're qualitative and they translate to quantitative. One is our OEs from a cost structure standpoint are in a better position than they've been historically. And I think that certainly is an incremental benefit. Two, I think when you look at vehicle mix, they're in a position where vehicle mix is better than what it's historical been. So there's some element of offering. Listen, I think as the market gets more challenged, will OEs potentially get more challenging from a pricing standpoint? Yes, possible. That's why Joe made the comments, and I've made the comments, in addition to our discussion about product portfolio and growth, we're always focused on the cost structure so that to the extent, if price-downs do go up and we need to respond to that, we have the ability to absorb that and still deliver strong margins.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would echo that. I mean, we're always focused on the potential for things like additional price and how to deal with them and the cost structure. And to be honest with you, I know you mentioned this, but we hear price all the time, right? And price
componenttext: Yes, I would echo that. I mean, we're always focused on the potential for things like additional price and how to deal with them and the cost structure. And to be honest with you, I know you mentioned this, but we hear price all the time, right? And price from customers is just as loud when volume's going up, and they view us as benefiting from higher volumes and they want some of that back. So it's a constant dialogue. And again, we often comment, the way we address things like price or things like volume is really continued focus on the cost structure.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Brinkman from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Brinkman from JPMorgan.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of the suppliers with commercial vehicle and off-highway exposure that have reported so far this quarter, they've pointed to the softer-than-expected end market conditions. Is that what you're seeing as well? And do you have a view on when it might b
componenttext: Most of the suppliers with commercial vehicle and off-highway exposure that have reported so far this quarter, they've pointed to the softer-than-expected end market conditions. Is that what you're seeing as well? And do you have a view on when it might bottom?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are seeing that as well. Our CV in the quarter was down about 4%. And we expect for the full year to be about 3% down for the year. So we hopefully are seeing that. I think on the bottom, at this point, '16 was certainly lower than we were originally e
componenttext: We are seeing that as well. Our CV in the quarter was down about 4%. And we expect for the full year to be about 3% down for the year. So we hopefully are seeing that. I think on the bottom, at this point, '16 was certainly lower than we were originally expecting. At this point, from a planning presumption, we're expecting '17 to be down slightly as well just as we go into this and want to make sure we're prepared. For us, it's -- I think the -- and it's off-road cycle in particular is a little tougher to call the bottom, just given that's a unique market, whereas assets are not being assets when think slowdown actually get parked and are not necessarily utilized. So even as the market starts to come back, you do have a little bit of catch-up on those assets before the replenishment cycle starts. We are seeing that. That is consistent with our view.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And kind of unrelated but still on commercial vehicles. Does your partnership with Mobileye extend to commercial vehicles also? Or are you otherwise going after the business? I ask because there seems to have been a pickup in interest recently regar
componenttext: Okay. And kind of unrelated but still on commercial vehicles. Does your partnership with Mobileye extend to commercial vehicles also? Or are you otherwise going after the business? I ask because there seems to have been a pickup in interest recently regarding autonomous trucks, maybe especially after Uber's famous autonomous beer delivery. So just curious if you're doing anything there.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Listen, our partnership with Mobileye is really focused on passenger car. But having said that, Brian, we've been focused on the commercial vehicle and have been dying dialogues with several of the commercial vehicle manufacturers about automated driving.
componenttext: Listen, our partnership with Mobileye is really focused on passenger car. But having said that, Brian, we've been focused on the commercial vehicle and have been dying dialogues with several of the commercial vehicle manufacturers about automated driving. And I'll tell you, I wouldn't say that's a new phenomenon to begin with. I think given -- again, given the fact that they have a commercial interest in fuel economy, they have a commercial interest in increased safety and driver productivity, we've been working with several CVs actually over the last couple of years with respect to adoption of automated driving technologies in that space.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joseph Spak from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joseph Spak from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, just going back to R&D. So clearly, a lot of interest, a lot of excitement and a lot of rapid change, which is why you're talking about some higher levels of R&D or engineering. But I was wondering, and maybe this is a little bit more diff
componenttext: First question, just going back to R&D. So clearly, a lot of interest, a lot of excitement and a lot of rapid change, which is why you're talking about some higher levels of R&D or engineering. But I was wondering, and maybe this is a little bit more difficult to quantify, like the level of reliance that your customers are putting on you for electrification or connectivity or active safety, has that increased, do you think, over the past year or so?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, listen, let me start with overall. I think the reliance on one technology; and two, probably maybe important systems integration has gone up. And I think a great example, for instance, is the multi-domain controller and integrated cockpit co
componenttext: Yes. I think, listen, let me start with overall. I think the reliance on one technology; and two, probably maybe important systems integration has gone up. And I think a great example, for instance, is the multi-domain controller and integrated cockpit controller that we're working on. So I would say, in general, it's gone up. Now there are some OEs who tend to want to do more on their own, and I think you can guess who those are. There are others who are more likely to outsource that to suppliers like ourselves. So it varies a little bit by OE. But I would say, in general, it's thrusted [ph] up.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Second question is just on HellermannTyton, actually. I wonder if we get an update. Like, if I look at your walks on sales and profit, just on acquisitions it looks like that margin was even margins are a little under 12%. I think it
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Second question is just on HellermannTyton, actually. I wonder if we get an update. Like, if I look at your walks on sales and profit, just on acquisitions it looks like that margin was even margins are a little under 12%. I think it's been there the past couple of quarters. I think it's probably a little bit below what HellermannTyton did historically. So just wondering if you could provide us an update on that integration and the savings. Or are those savings coming in, in some other bucket? And I guess, related also, is the pound weakening a headwind there for that business? Or has it been a headwind?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me -- listen, the business is doing great, and the integration is actually ahead of schedule. I'll let Joe comment on the rest of your question.
componenttext: Let me -- listen, the business is doing great, and the integration is actually ahead of schedule. I'll let Joe comment on the rest of your question.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think on that, on the acquisitions line in that bridge on '16, we have perception systems coming out. So there is a little bit of depression on the margin. So that business is growing at 10%, which was in line with -- we were focused on 9% to 10% g
componenttext: Yes. I think on that, on the acquisitions line in that bridge on '16, we have perception systems coming out. So there is a little bit of depression on the margin. So that business is growing at 10%, which was in line with -- we were focused on 9% to 10% growth in the acquisition model. It's hitting its margin target, its historical margin trends. And the synergy number, which is $50 million for 2018, will be -- will certainly be at that, and we're striving to be slightly above it on a run-rate basis for '18. So things are going well with that deal. It's a nice business, it's a good fit for Delphi and it's a very well-run business, very strong management team that has remained with Delphi and continues to run that business.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: And and build up that way? Okay, got you. And then longer term, China [indiscernible] 2017. Any kind of preliminary idea of what they may institute and how that would impact your business as in a tailwind for maybe radar, camera, et cetera?

componenttext: Yes. Listen, it's, I would say, high level of confidence that they'll will implement some elements of NCAP. Not completely sure what specific items. It will be -- it will definitely be a tailwind for active safety, and we'd expect the benefit from it. The reality is our bookings -- we have some bookings, active safety bookings, in China, some more recently, quite frankly. But it's not a big number that we're coming off of. So I would view that as longer-term potential upside.

componenttext: Yes, active safety year-to-date is a little less than $900 million of bookings.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttextpreview: Yes, Itay, we're still working through the year. Obviously, I think, as we talk through things like market and FX rates from a '17 perspective, those are obviously carried through to the '18 numbers. But at this point, that's -- we haven't really done muc
componenttext: Yes, Itay, we're still working through the year. Obviously, I think, as we talk through things like market and FX rates from a '17 perspective, those are obviously carried through to the '18 numbers. But at this point, that's -- we haven't really done much beyond that as we work through '17.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then back to 2017. Given the uptick in restructuring spending this year, how should we think about kind of the net performance relative to pricing in 2017? Is that a potentially a bigger source of margin expansion for your next year?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then back to 2017. Given the uptick in restructuring spending this year, how should we think about kind of the net performance relative to pricing in 2017? Is that a potentially a bigger source of margin expansion for your next year?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly, we took actions this year. We took actions earlier in the year, planned actions. As I've talked about, we accelerated them, particularly the closure of a powertrain facility in Western Europe. We continue to work our overhead structure dow
componenttext: Yes, certainly, we took actions this year. We took actions earlier in the year, planned actions. As I've talked about, we accelerated them, particularly the closure of a powertrain facility in Western Europe. We continue to work our overhead structure down, and that all accrues to the benefit of '17. And for us, it really goes back to what I was talking about, and we're in the process now of how much do we reinvest in the business alongside the growth that we're seeing while expanded margining. So for us, we're doing that on the cost side to be able to do both, expand margins and invest appropriate levels in key technologies. And I think as you see in the growth rates in E&S this quarter, it's 17%. We clearly think there's opportunity there and quite honestly, more opportunity down the road to be investing in it.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Itay, I think it's important. Joe, [indiscernible] explain, listen, a lot of our focus on cost structure optimization is one to offset price downs in economics. But to the extent we can drive incremental productivity, other areas where we can make sm
componenttext: Yes, Itay, I think it's important. Joe, [indiscernible] explain, listen, a lot of our focus on cost structure optimization is one to offset price downs in economics. But to the extent we can drive incremental productivity, other areas where we can make smart investments, all of which are variable, by the way. It's not investments in brick-and-mortar or fixed costs. But other areas where we can make smart investments that allow us to drive future growth.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just lastly. I think, Kevin, you mentioned seeing some customer interest for the level 4, 5 offering you have with the Mobileye partnership. I was hoping we could talk a little bit more about that. And specifically, are you seeing kind
componenttext: That's helpful. And just lastly. I think, Kevin, you mentioned seeing some customer interest for the level 4, 5 offering you have with the Mobileye partnership. I was hoping we could talk a little bit more about that. And specifically, are you seeing kind of any interest to onboard in 2019? And are your customers kind of looking to apply this system for more of a right turn environment initially or kind of the direct sale to consumers for the level 4 and 5?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, listen, I think, it's -- I think given the dialogue we're having with select customers, they could have them in their vehicles close to 2019 or before 2021, put it that way, given some of the dialogs we're working. So in terms of pulling it forward,
componenttext: Yes, listen, I think, it's -- I think given the dialogue we're having with select customers, they could have them in their vehicles close to 2019 or before 2021, put it that way, given some of the dialogs we're working. So in terms of pulling it forward, obviously, what's critical is that our partnership begins working with OEs sooner rather than later to integrate that. Whether it's with respect to ridesharing or it goes in their normal consumer fleet, I don't have any answer to that question, Itay. I don't know.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to drill down a tiny bit more on the diesel, I guess, the diesel mix risk going into next year. Do you have any sort of rule of thumb on content? I guess, diesel versus -- so you said diesel versus gas, but let's say, customers actually just r
componenttext: Just wanted to drill down a tiny bit more on the diesel, I guess, the diesel mix risk going into next year. Do you have any sort of rule of thumb on content? I guess, diesel versus -- so you said diesel versus gas, but let's say, customers actually just replaced their diesel vehicle with a GDi gas engine, what would be sort of the content impact for you?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- round numbers, Emmanuel, we view it as 500 on the diesel side, 300 on the gas. So gas is roughly 60% of diesel, generally speaking, from a content perspective for us.
componenttext: Yes, we -- round numbers, Emmanuel, we view it as 500 on the diesel side, 300 on the gas. So gas is roughly 60% of diesel, generally speaking, from a content perspective for us.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the 300 already included a GDi system on it?
componenttext: So the 300 already included a GDi system on it?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, we work with averages here, right? Every OE is a little different. But think of it as 60% gas GDi versus diesel.
componenttext: Yes. Again, we work with averages here, right? Every OE is a little different. But think of it as 60% gas GDi versus diesel.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then just going back on the interest that you're seeing with the autonomous system with Mobileye. Can you -- the customers you're talking to about it, are they generally automakers looking to specifically for turn-key solution and wo
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then just going back on the interest that you're seeing with the autonomous system with Mobileye. Can you -- the customers you're talking to about it, are they generally automakers looking to specifically for turn-key solution and would like to sort of like invest in there? Is there a specific profile for interest in the system? Or is it generally as part of the overall autonomous discussion? And how do they go about deciding whether this is the right system or whether it would be something where they'll have more, I guess, direct involvement?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's both, both OEs who would want a straight turn-key solution who, historically, in the future, don't look at kind of what they have in terms of resources or value-add being development of o a system and incorporating what they do with what we would do
componenttext: It's both, both OEs who would want a straight turn-key solution who, historically, in the future, don't look at kind of what they have in terms of resources or value-add being development of o a system and incorporating what they do with what we would do as well as worked with some OEs who historically are very strong from a software standpoint, very strong from a technology standpoint, who would be involved in what it is that our partnership is doing. So there isn't a "typical" ends of the spectrum.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that's great to hear. And then just very quickly, on your electrification content opportunity. So obviously, very big potential increases versus the current powertrain content. As some of these content-based sort of like early pricing because b
componenttext: All right, that's great to hear. And then just very quickly, on your electrification content opportunity. So obviously, very big potential increases versus the current powertrain content. As some of these content-based sort of like early pricing because benefit from, I guess, being low-volume and therefore, fairly high price but could see some meaningful price reductions as volume come up? Or do these content number already incorporate sort of like normalized volume assumption is?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say it's were normalized at this point. Remember, a big part of that for us is a electrical content architecture content. So that is well known, the cost in the marketplace -- and the cost of the marketplace is well known for that. So this is
componenttext: Yes, I would say it's were normalized at this point. Remember, a big part of that for us is a electrical content architecture content. So that is well known, the cost in the marketplace -- and the cost of the marketplace is well known for that. So this isn't -- there's a lot for us. Electrification is important because it's very much of her bread-and-butter particularly as relates Electrical Architecture. So I think of it as more of a normalized.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Emmanuel, one thing I want to add to your question about diesel versus gas. And I think this is -- it's really important. When you talk to our OE customers, especially on the European side with respect to light-duty diesel, to the extent there's a decline
componenttext: Emmanuel, one thing I want to add to your question about diesel versus gas. And I think this is -- it's really important. When you talk to our OE customers, especially on the European side with respect to light-duty diesel, to the extent there's a decline in light-duty diesel penetration rates and there's an increase in Gas Direct Injection, the reality is without more light-duty diesel, they can't meet standards that are out there. So they're going to need to overlay increased vehicle electrification to achieve that. So as we give you the trade-off between light-duty diesel and GDi, just spot on, it's kind of $0.60 on the dollar trade-off, you do really need to overlay some element of increased electrification, whether that's 48-volt, whether it's full hybrid or plug-in hybrid, whatever the case may be. So I don't think the calculus is simple as saying less light-duty penetration replaced with lower content Gas Direct Injection. There has to be an electrification quantification that you need to roll into your assumption to fully assess the impact.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that need immediate? Or can the automakers afford to wait a few years before one of those regulation milestone?
componenttext: Is that need immediate? Or can the automakers afford to wait a few years before one of those regulation milestone?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. If you look at the EU emissions regulations on CO2 is 2021. The fuel economy is 2025 in North America. So it's -- we're getting close, and they certainly need to think through it. And then you've got the added complexity of the additional content that
componenttext: No. If you look at the EU emissions regulations on CO2 is 2021. The fuel economy is 2025 in North America. So it's -- we're getting close, and they certainly need to think through it. And then you've got the added complexity of the additional content that gets added to the vehicle. There is additional demand on -- for electricity within the vehicle, which places more demand on internal combustion engine. So I think, like, 48-volt become relevant very quickly.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So if we were to think about the growth in 48-volt systems, do we think that, that some of that would accrue to the powertrain and not just the EEA?

componenttext: Yes. The would -- power electronics. The growth we're seeing in power electronics would now be in powertrain, yes.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The second question is kind of a big-picture question about the bookings data. If I look at your year-over-year bookings data, if I look at the long-term growth, it's a plus 10%. If I look at the quarterly number, it's down 29. If I look at the roll
componenttext: Okay. The second question is kind of a big-picture question about the bookings data. If I look at your year-over-year bookings data, if I look at the long-term growth, it's a plus 10%. If I look at the quarterly number, it's down 29. If I look at the rolling fourth quarter, it's down 23. If I look at the 8 year-to-year figure, figure to date, it's minus 18. And I know these things are clumpy. I guess, I just look at the state. And I wonder what it is that we should be driving from it because it's so assumption-laden. And what is it that you want us as investors to walk away with?

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a moment. I think one thing in particular. We had a very large award in Q1 of '15 that we've talked about since, plus $3 billion in the quarter. So that does -- and I would say when bookings are lumpy, timing from quarter-to-quarter is a littl
componenttext: Let me take a moment. I think one thing in particular. We had a very large award in Q1 of '15 that we've talked about since, plus $3 billion in the quarter. So that does -- and I would say when bookings are lumpy, timing from quarter-to-quarter is a little challenging. But that one is was proportionately large and still affecting some of those year-over-year and quarter comps as you think through it.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, I would -- bigger picture. I think this is one indicator of the strength of the revenue line. You're right, I wouldn't say, I don't know if I call them assumptions at the end of the day. I called them a number of variables get factored into thi
componenttext: Yes, Matt, I would -- bigger picture. I think this is one indicator of the strength of the revenue line. You're right, I wouldn't say, I don't know if I call them assumptions at the end of the day. I called them a number of variables get factored into this, right, at a point in time. It's global production, it's specific vehicle production, it's specific take rates within a vehicle, it's specific regions. So you're absolutely -- at foreign exchange, commodity prices. So you're absolutely right that it's not a simple calculation. I think the way that I've kind of ultimately resided this is one of several indicators for revenue growth that guys like you ought to look at. It shouldn't translate dollar-for-dollar in any given quarter or any given year. But it's one thing to think about and to consider. It's one additional bit of information that we can give you guys to talk about what we're doing, what it is we're seeing from a technology standpoint, where our revenues should ultimately mix out to what sort of product lines and with what customers.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Our final question comes from the line of Colin Langan from UBS.

headline: Delphi Automotive PLC, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
